that the deficit last year amounted to $500, and suggesting that if the number of pupils, which is at present 25, were doubled the same staff & the same buildings would be sufficient and that the school could then be carried on at the per capita rate of $130 per annum, and that the Indians are most anxious to send their children, and that it is marvellous to see the change in the boys & girls under the discipline of the Sisters for a year, - the undersigned beg to report that at its last session Parliament voted $6250 towards the maintenance of the school in question, being at the rate of $130 each for 50 pupils; but it appears that through some oversight on the part of the Dept., no intelligence was
conveyed to the Indian Superintendent at Victoria of such additional grant having been made. The undersigned has taken steps to have this defect remedied by having the authorities of the school informed, through Capt. Vowell, of the additional grant.

Ottawa, December 7th, 1892.

My Dear Sir John,

With reference to the Hon. James Baker's letter of the 15th ultimo, addressed to you, on the subject of increased aid to the Kootenay Industrial School, I was glad to be able to inform Mr. Baker, in a letter which I have today written him, that the Church authorities in charge of the school may increase the number of pupils from 25 to 50, at the per capita rate of $130 per annum each.

The Indian Superintendent at Victoria has been duly advised of this.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

The Honourable

Sir John D. Thompson, K.C.M.G.,

Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 7th, 1892.

Dear Mr. Baker,

Sir John Thompson has handed me your letter of the 15th ultimo, in which you express a desire that greater assistance may be given the Kootenay Industrial School.

I am glad to be in a position to inform you that provision has been made for an increased number of pupils. The Church authorities may therefore increase the attendance to 50 pupils, at the per capita rate of $130 each.

Mr. Superintendent Vowell of Victoria has been instructed to notify the School authorities accordingly.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) J. Hayne Daly

Hon. James Baker,
Victoria,
B. C.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that one of the pupils of the Industrial School who left the School early in the spring and who settled at the Columbia Lake (Kootenay) Reserve called on me today and requested me to write you on his behalf; he is most anxious to get a set of carpenters tools so that he can do some work for his people on the Reserve, when at the school he learned a little of the carpenter trade, and succeeded very well for the opportunity he had.

His name is "Ignatius" he was at school about four years, and was very well behaved and attentive to his studies. Hoping that you will give the matter your earnest attention.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your Obedient servant

(sgd) R.L.T. Galbraith

Fort Steele, Oct 21st 1897

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th ultimo, asking for further information about "Ignatius," I have the honor to inform you that when he left the School he had a fair knowledge of shoemaking as well as carpentry, and he had worked for a short time at Fort Steele at the former trade as the schoolmaster did not suit him. The Rev. Father Coecke O.M.I., gave him some outdoor work, excavating for the basement of the New Mission Church at St. Eugene's. When the contract for the Church was let, I saw the foreman talk to Ignatius and asked him to give "Ignatius" employment as a carpenter at the Church, thus the foreman consented to do so and the lad had steady employment during the summer which gave him an opportunity of improving his knowledge of the trade. His wages at first were $1.50 per day and with board and afterwards $2.00. When there was some difficulty about getting dry lumber to complete the work, the foreman had to dispense with his services, and he went to Tobacco Plains to assist with the harvest.

CANADA
Fort Steele, Oct. 1st 1897

Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that "Tawtis" one of the pupils at the Industrial School has applied to the Rt. Principal for his discharge as he wants to return to his home at Tobacco Plains. During his stay at the School he was one of the most attentive pupils at his studies and made satisfactory progress. He has a good knowledge of carpentry and I take pleasure in recommending him to the consideration of the Department for a set of carpenter tools so as to give him a fair start in life and an opportunity of doing some work for his hand when he returns to his home.

In the meantime I hope to be enabled to work at the New Church at St. Eugene's Mission where he will have a chance of still further gaining a good knowledge of carpentry.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A.M. Vassell Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs.

R.T. Haltbreck,
Agent.

Sir:

I have the honor to inform you of the difficulty under which we labor in regard to the water supply for our School. The two wells about thirty feet deep are completely dry, and large boulders prevent us from sinking farther.

The only way to secure water would be by gravitation. In building a dam six feet high in Joseph Creek at a point, two thousand feet above the houses and sinking four inches pipe five feet below surface, we could rise the water up to the roof; thus protecting ourselves against fire.

The said pipes having to be laid through the Indian Village, we could supply both School and Village by means of taps. I enclose a sketch of the dam to give you an idea of the possibility of success.

Material and workmanship according to my estimation would amount to $1500, but to reduce expenses the boys under the direction of a practical man could do the work.

I have the honor to be,

Sir:—

I have the honor to inform you that for some time past the supply of water at the Industrial School from the wells has been very unsatisfactory and when visiting the institution recently, I carefully looked into the matter with the Revd. Principal Coccolia, and found that during the cold weather the water got very low, just at a time when it was most required for domestic and other purposes.

To give a better system, we agreed that the supply should be taken from Joseph Creek, a short distance above the Perry Creek trail, with a dam put at that point, so as to raise the water, a good and sufficient supply could be given both to the Industrial School and Indian Village.

OTTAWA, 29th April, 1904:

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr. Supt. Vowell forwards under date of the 20th instant an application from the Principal of the Kootenay Industrial school for a grant for the purpose of installing a permanent water supply in the institution. The intention is to dam a creek and lay a pipe line to the school. An eight-foot dam would give sufficient head to reach all parts of the building by reavitation.

In the present water supply is uncertain, as stated, another plan should be adopted, and the one of drawing water from a reservoir with sufficient fall would be the best and most economical in the end. If funds can be found I do not see that the money could
be better spent than in overcoming this difficulty.

The scheme proposed is similar to the one adopted for the McDougall Orphanage at Morley for which the Department has agreed to pay, although the buildings are the property of the Methodist Church, while in this instance the school is owned by the Government.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that, on the 26th of last month, August 26th, a pupil attending the Industrial School got drowned whilst skating on a lake near St. Mary's River.

On my return from Windermere I went over to the Industrial School and found the particulars in connection with the sad accident to be as follows:

It was customary for the Sisters to have the cattle let loose near the School grounds across the St. Mary's River to graze and to take them in the afternoon back to the school premises. On the afternoon of August 26th, the Sisters informed me that the cattle had been let loose and that they had returned as quickly as possible. The cattle had been heard barking and in some way managed to take his shepherd. He had not returned within a reasonable time so the Sisters concluded that something might be wrong, so they sent out Indians and others employed at the Institution to make a search. When his body was found, he was lying on the bank of the river, where the boy had gone skating, and dropped through. When the body was recovered every effort was made to resuscitate him, but without success.

I investigated the case carefully and found that no blame could be attached to those in charge of the School.

The boy was a promising pupil and the only son of an Indian named James Joseph of this district.

Dear Sir,

It is gratifying to state a few problems that is confronting us today. As an ex-pupil I would like to draw your attention to a few facts of the conditions of this (footnoted) Reserve. Which I hope you will not turn a deaf ear. When the Agency was first established did the Government make some agreements with the Indians or did they not.

To begin with we shall start with the school and its surroundings. As I have stated before I am an ex-pupil. I shall dwell on a subject that myself had hundreds during the period of my school days, and which I might state nothing was done to better the conditions of the pupils since.

It has been known, and it has come to be publicly known, and it is a matter of general
talk of the conditions of the pupils. That they are taken out in the fields and in the woods a whole day or half a day as the case may be and there be telling doing work that a grown up person would be paid for doing. And the third man who is paid a salary for doing the work standing right behind them if one stops a moment to rest he is made to work of course I refer to the smaller boys six and seven years old it make me think of the days of slavery.

And here I might state that the Indians have come to hinder it. And for the reason it has been more of a task to induce the people to give up their children to the principal of the school. And which I have reason to think will be the case till something is done to better the conditions of the pupils.

In 1913 when the school was completed the biggest school that was ever built.
In the interest of B.C. for the Indians by
the Government.

No doubt the Indians were very grateful
to those who undertook such a great
task at such an expense. They all
looked at that building as a place
where the Indian would be ignorant
of the world beyond, and after a few
years of education come out of there

which he would be willing to impart
to his less fortunate brothers. And which
would also put the Indian on the same

thought and expression.

But after they saw that nothing

they stepped back and waited for the day
when a change for the better would
come over the landscape, which to my
opinion has not claimed yet.

The next thing I will draw your
attention to is the condition of the pupils after they are graduated. And this I think will appeal to the Indian Agent in charge of these four Reserves. Did the Department of Indian Affairs during the time of its existence ever state or promised that after a pupil graduated they would give such a pupil a start in the new way that he became acquainted during the course of his school career. Which would be accomplished by giving them a small loan also implements with which to start with. If they did I fail to see where such an agreement was ever put into operation.

And furthermore I hope you will also give this matter your consideration. The pupils are being misled they are convinced that there is a missing link somewhere who is the responsible party they do not know.
The party that the people regard as the instrument through which their pleas could be heard by the Government seems to be the barrier which obstructs their desperate calls from being heard by the Government.

The people are tired of promises made to them by the Agent. It would have been better that these promises were never made. Did the Government ever send any money for the relief of the poor and aged? If they did, they fail to see where it was ever distributed among them. The wants of the people that the compensation made by the Government to the people were known almost after they were made. Did the Government make these promises or was it someone that just said it, pretending that he was acting in the name of the Government?

The people are thoroughly convinced that they are misled by someone who

What they want is some responsible person that is willing to play square with the people, a responsible party whom they would have no cause to distrust, whom they can look upon as their benefactor in the hour of need and feel that they are being led on the road success and modern civilization. Report No.:

Trouble amongst Indians - Cranbrook, B.C.

On instructions from Sergt. Hanna I proceeded to Cranbrook by train on the morning of the 15th inst., in connection with the above matter. On my arrival there I reported as directed to Mr. Helmsing, the Indian Agent, who requested me to go to the Indian Mission School, six miles east, as there had been some discontent amongst the Indians with regard to school affairs and the sisters were afraid of trouble.

From my conversation with Mr. Helmsing and from other sources I found that there had been some discontent amongst the Indians on the reserve over the refusal of the Indian agent to let certain children, pupils at the school, attend the ceremony of the opening of the Banff-Windermere road at Invermere on June 30th. This coupled with the fact that there is a new staff in charge at the school appears to have caused some friction amongst the Indians, so much so that the Indian Chief, Francis Francois, warned the sisters on the 12th inst. that they had better leave Cranbrook on the next train to avoid trouble.

I passed the night of the 15th on guard at the school during which I made frequent patrols in the vicinity, but everything passed off quietly and I saw no signs of any Indians. On the 14th I visited the Indian village some distance from the school but saw only two or three Indian men and women, the rest being on their farms on the reserve. The school and village are both on the reserve, being about a hundred yards apart.

As there appeared to be no further signs of trouble I returned to Fernie by train on the night of the 14th.

I most respectfully beg to submit for your approval a suggestion regarding the Kootenay Industrial School.

At the beginning of the School year which has just closed I promised the girls and boys prizes for the two boys and the two girls who, during the school year, received the least number of bad marks against their respective names.

My suggestion which I have to make is that the Department will authorise me to offer prizes as follows each School year, to be awarded at the commencement of the summer vacation:

- 1st Prize for best girl: $5.00
- 2nd Prize for best girl: $2.50
- 1st Prize for best boy: $5.00
- 2nd Prize for best boy: $2.50

When I say best girl and boy, I mean general all round proficiency and good behaviour. This year I have awarded the prizes, and I am sure the competition has been responsible for making the children try to win the prize and consequently made better girls and boys. After all the white schools give prizes and the children have something to look forward to, while the Indian children get no acknowledgement for any signs of improvement, the bad or careless pupils being treated the same as the ambitious.

Sir:

Through frequent meetings with the Indians, I find that there is a very lively and strongly expressed antipathy to the school. The chief complaint of the Indians is that the boys, particularly the younger ones, are far too heavily worked at such work as logging for the school supply of fuel in the winter, and that the boys are quite insufficiently dressed to be exposed to the cold weather in such work. The fact that so many boys died there this Spring of pneumonia, also aggravated and lent colour to their complaints. They also complain of insufficient food. Of course they have taken their complaints as largely exaggerated. However, there it is, and even under close questioning they persist in it.

Mr. Helminger also informed me of the strong prejudice and the consequent trouble involved in getting the children back to school. I cannot, therefore, believe that there is nothing in it. That is, however, a new Principal, the Rev. Mother Mary de Sena, and I went into the matter very fully with her, warning her that it is entirely up to her to overcome this prejudice, if the school is to be a success. I fully explained to her the Indians' complaints, without disguising any of them. She seems to be fully alive to the seriousness of it, and I should think, is a most sensible, practicable and kindhearted lady, with previous extensive experience of Indian nature. I feel sure that she will make a great improvement, and extend sympathy and a bit of "Blarney" to the Indian parents, which after all is only what all parents require, whether red or white. I can only think in the past few years there, that this has been missing and is at the bottom of the matter. Perhaps, too, the fact that the outdoor work has to be left in the hands of hired help has not helped matters, particularly over the logging business. I have informed Mother Superior, and she quite sees the point. The school has also been warned against taking timber off the Reserve for firewood, that is merchantable.

In connection with school matters, I would like to point out that in this agency, as in others, there is a great difficulty in getting the children from distant points to school. One of the principal reasons being that the average Indian finds great difficulty in finding money for fees. I think it would be of great assistance if in all cases of distant travelling advantage was taken of Sec. 9, sub 4, of the Indian act.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) G. S. Pragnell.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

I regret very much having to report that 6 more boys, pupils of the Kootenay Industrial School have been arrested by the Provincial Police Department for burglaries which have happened around here recently, on more than one occasion. The Police suspected Indian boys, but I could not believe this knowing that the boys were all in school at the time the theft they mentioned to me took place.

However, upon being advised of their suspicions by Chief Constable Mortimer, I visited the school in his company with a view to making full inquiries.

From the boys themselves, who made no pretence to hide the fact, rather glorying in their adventures, we ascertained that several of the boys of late had been getting up at about midnight, dressing, going out by way of the dormitory window, taking horses from the school barn and going to Fort Steele, a distance of some 7 miles from the school. Here they broke into the general store of the Fort Steele Trading Co. and stole food, tobacco, cigarettes, chewing gum, pocket knives, shoes, clothes etc., some of which Chief Mortimer and I recovered from caches in the school basement. They then returned to the school, climbed up the walls by the help of a rope they had smuggled into the dormitory, went to bed and claimed nothing had happened. The two brothers Schelle, the two hired men at the school, seem also to be quite aware, in a little room between the two boys' dormitories, having an opening on each side of their room into the respective dormitories. How the boys could get up, dress, set out of the windows, and a few hours later, return by the same way, and not wake either of these two men, is beyond my comprehension altogether, yet they claim they never heard any sound.

I might mention here that on more than one previous occasion, Mr. Schelle has told me that he heard footsteps on the school corridors, and he said he thought that someone had broken in from the outside and was in the building. Yet, he apparently never got up to investigate, whether he was afraid or not I cannot say. Evidently as it turns out now, it was some of the school boys themselves walking around the building. When these matters were reported to me, investigations were made which gave us no clues to anybody having broken into the building, and now the whole matter stands out as clear as daylight. It was the boys in the building who would not leave any trace of having broken in from the outside.

On Saturday last, the 22nd inst., Sister Superior reported to me that on one occasion, Mr. Schelle caught some of the boys getting up in the middle of the night and he made them get back into bed again. The matter was not however, reported to me until the 22nd inst., although it happened some few weeks ago.
The Sister Superior was away from here on her annual Lenten "retreat" and Sister Francis was in charge of the boys. Not knowing at that time that the boys had been away by the same process previously, and as they had caught them and prevented them from leaving the school, the matter was not reported to me as it should have been, the school staff thinking they could prevent the repetition of the affair.

Now as it happens, it turns out the boys have done this before and the Superior regrets very much not having reported it to me at the time mentioned.

I spoke very seriously to the Superior on the matter and asked her if she considered the Messrs Scholle to be competent to care for the boys, as I had my doubts about it. She assured me they are, although I must admit there must have been slackness somewhere.

The 6 boys in question, Jimmy Isaac aged 15 years, and Louie Paul, Skookum Joe, John George, Joe Mission and Joseph Dominic are all around 12-13 years of age.

Skookum Joe is the bad one and leader of the gang, and this is his 4th offence of running away and entering and stealing from houses and stores, and I am strongly of the opinion that it was he that lead the other boys off on these occasions. Only a couple of weeks ago he ran away with John George, and stole horses, going to Canoe Flats and Fairmont Springs, some 91 mile away, breaking into stores en route and taking articles. At this time, on the plea of the Rev Father Tedrow, the Judge allowed them both off on 5 years suspended sentence.

Whether this is all being done to test out my stand regarding the Administration of Justice among Indians, which has been very much to the fore of late, vide my letter No.: 2298-25 under date December 29th, 1923, or not I cannot say, but my personal impression is that this has something to do with it, because, when Skookum Joe and John George were brought before the Courts some two weeks ago, the Indians demanded that they be handed over to them to be punished, as the white man's court had no right to do so. Having previously warned the Judge of this idea of the Indians, I got him to give them a good straight talk on the matter, and told them to understand that once and for all, the Indians came under the laws just the same as their white brothers, and that this would never be changed.

The 6 boys in question come before His Hon Judge Thompson, in Cranbrook on Monday the 31st inst., and I will report at that time, as to the decision of the Court in the matter.

Most respectfully submitted,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Friend,

A few lines to tell you what happened in Court yesterday, regarding the six boys who were charged with house breaking etc.

The five boys came up before His Hon Judge Thompson, Joseph Dominic did not come up because he is still in Hospital.

The five pleaded guilty and elected to be tried by Speedy Trial before His Hon. After the Crown Counsel had addressed the Judge, I spoke on behalf of the boys, stating that in the case of Skookum Joe I was not going to ask for any favour as this was Joe's fourth offence and he deserved all he got. Regarding the four boys, Jimmy Isaac, Louie Paul, John George and Joe Mission, I asked His Hon: to give these four boys another chance as they were not bad boys and I felt that another chance might be given them to show that they were not bad boys. I asked for suspended sentence in these cases.

His Hon: in reply to me said that he was sick and tired of these kind of cases and that the boys must be taught, as well as the older Indians, that such things must not be allowed to go on. He thought that suspended sentence was no good at all and that apparently the boys took notice of it. He said he had let Skookum Joe and John George out on 5 years suspended sentence only a few weeks ago at Wilmer and he had hoped that that would be a warning to all the boys, but apparently they took no notice of it, but went right ahead and did the same thing a few days afterwards.

As John George had not committed any offence since he had warned him at Wilmer, and as Joe Mission's offence was committed before the warning to the two boys at Wilmer he was going to let these two boys go on 5 years suspended sentence. Regarding Skookum Joe he sentenced him to 5 years in the reformatory. Louie Paul had gone with Skookum Joe only a few days after Joe had been warned, so that there
that there) was absolutely no excuse for him at all that he could see and he sent him to the reformatory for 4 years. Jimmy Isaac, he said was old enough to know better and in his opinion, should have tried to persuade the younger boys not to commit these offences; on the other hand he believed that Jimmy Isaac was to blame for persuading the boys to commit the offences and also took part in the crimes, so he sent him to Oakalla Farm for 2 years. Joseph Dominic has not been before His Honor yet.

It has made my heart very sad to think of all these boys having done this, especially after the other boys were punished only a few months ago, and I could not get the Judge to allow them out on suspended sentence at all, and he further said that if any more boys do the same kind of things again he is going to send them away too.

Your friend,

H.F. Helmung,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 13th inst., regarding the application made by Rev. Father Smith, Principal of the Kootenay Residential School, for the release of several boys at present serving various terms of imprisonment at Okanagan Prison Farm and at the Provincial Reformatory.

With respect to these boys, I beg to make the following recommendations or suggestions, and knowing the circumstances of all these cases, you will perhaps permit me to assume that I am in a good position to recommend, or otherwise.

Last spring there was an organized gang of male pupils at the school above mentioned, who, according to their own statements, and in spite of repeated warnings from Rev. Sister M. du Closse, who at that time was Principal, from myself as Indian Agent for the Kootenay at that time, and in some cases from the parents, also in spite of flagrants given the boys by the Indian Chief in the presence of the remaining pupils at that time attending school, were bound to commit some crime or crimes in order that they might be sent to the Reformatory, as, in their opinion, they thought that they would have a much better time there than in school, and would, perhaps, only be kept there for a short while and then paroled. Their idea was that when this happened, the Department would not consent to their re-admittance to the School after having served said terms, and they would consequently be free to go as they pleased.

These statements were made in open Court to His Honour Judge Thompson, who tried and sentenced these boys. The boys made no secret of their plans and intentions when they were caught, and one or two of them made the boast that they were going to do these things, although neither the school authorities nor myself ever considered that they would carry their threats into operation.

Two or three of the boys had appeared before Mr. John Leask, Stipendiary Magistrate for the City of Cranbrook, and also His Honour Judge Thompson, and were warned and allowed out on suspended sentence, but these warnings had no effect at all. When they were taken back to school they launched out again in a day or so in the same kind of mischief.

There was at that time considerable unrest in the school among the boys, due, I am positive, to the agitation of the older members of this gang, Basil Andrew, Carimer Joseph, Jim Isaac, Pierre Andrew, and Damian Isaac, together with two younger and incorrigible boys, Alban Mike and Skookum Joe.

That this combination was responsible for these depredations there is no doubt, and this is corroborated by the fact that since they have been removed from the School, there has been perfect harmony and peace among the male pupils attending the school.

W.H.Small, Esq.
I am in no way wishing to penalize any of these boys, or their parents without justification, but, to my mind, it would be regrettable and unwise to permit these boys to be released from their respective punishments at the present time, as that would be belittling the law in the eyes of the Indians, and it would be defeating the ends of justice to return these boys to the School or the Reserve, as it would have tendency to create unrest among the boy pupils present in the School, who, as I said above, have behaved down, and appear to be perfectly happy and satisfied at the present time.

There are, perhaps, two cases which might be given some consideration. I refer to Joseph Dominic and Louis Paul. These two boys have always been good boys and they have never caused any trouble prior to this time, and I am convinced that they were led astray by the other boys implicated. Joseph has suffered considerably from injuries sustained while truant from the school, and I am sure has learned his lesson, which after all, is all that is required. I would suggest or recomment that these two cases be given consideration, but I will never agree in the cases of the other boys.

The Rev. Sister Superior, Sister Mary du Censicle, might also be able to enlighten the Department in these cases referred to, as the circumstances are well known to her, and I am convinced that if she were still Principal, she would never agree to take the leaders of the gang back into the School again.

The boys are being instructed where they are, and are being well cared for, and Mr. Brunkin, the Superintendent of the Reformatory is an excellent man to train and control boys of this calibre, so that the boys are in no way suffering as far as education is concerned, and they undoubtedly require correction before they get too old, otherwise they may become confirmed criminals.

Yours obediently,
(sgd) H.F. Helmsing,
Indian Agent.
I have the honour to enclose herewith Mr. H.F. Helmsing's, the late Agent's report on the Indian boys now serving terms in Okhalla Prison Farm and Reformatory at New Westminster.

In the last two weeks I have visited the different reservations and at each Council I held with the Indians their one complaint was "these boys", unnecessarily, or as they put it unjustly detained.

The Bands being small, they are nearly all related in one way or another, and this being the case it creates a general feeling of sympathy among them, and I also find that it is having a very bad effect on getting the other boys back to school, the parents fearing that if their boys go back, we are liable to send them away to prison, and in this state of mind it is no easy task for Mr. F.S. Ryckman and myself to persuade them that under the Reverend Father Smith, they will be well cared for.

Under separate cover I am mailing you today two bills from the Vancouver General Hospital. Both boys seems to be affected with Tuberculosis, and would be much better at home.

While we are anxious that the ends of Justice be met, we must take into consideration the undeveloped and uneducated mind of the older Indians, remembering that they are human, but still in a state of semi-civilization.

Now, my one object with them is to bring about harmony in this disturbed Agency. If you cannot see your way clear to bring them back and place them in Father Smith's care I sincerely hope
you may be able to consider Jim Isaac and Damian Isaac, the two boys in the Hospital, for I truly fear the result, should either of these boys die while there.

Joe Dominic and Louis Paul have not been bad boys, and I also trust you will consider their release.

I had a conversation this morning with His Honour Judge Thompson this morning, re Basil Andrew, eighteen years of age, now serving in Okhalla. The Judge seemed to think that the boy had not been sufficiently punished at the present time, but that he would be willing a little later on to consider his release. I spoke to him of the younger boys in the Reformatory, and he told me that he would be very pleased to see them taken out and put under the Reverend Father Smith's care.

I sincerely hope, Sir, that you will consider this letter in the spirit that it is meant. While its meaning and intent differs from that of the late Agent, the Reverend Father Smith is in accordance and feels sure that he could bring about a better result in the School.

I might say that I am paying special attention to the School, and will endeavor to make the older boys more contented, and do not anticipate any trouble with them this term.

This is respectfully submitted, Sir.

E.H.Small,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

The Reverend Father Smith, the Departmental Principal, as I understand it, of the St. Eugene Mission Industrial School called on me this morning, complaining that he has not got the power that is invested in other Principals in schools at Kamloops and different places in the Province.

He complains that he is not in a position to post the rules and teaching hours of the school that I have asked the teachers to carry out. Heretofore teaching hours in the school excepting junior classes have only been in the morning, no afternoon classes. The Indians complain that there is too much work and not enough study in the school, and the children are not being taught as they should be.

I have tried to reason this matter out with the different teachers, but find that there is an undercurrent working in the school, and there is no harmony between teachers and Principal. This is working a hardship on all concerned. I find it a very hard task to get the children back to the school after the holidays. We have at present only about fifty-six, in the school where we should have at least one hundred.

Constable Ryckman has been working almost continuously since the first of September to try and get the children in, but the Indians block him on pretty nearly every occasion. It seems that they have been in the habit of keeping the children out of the School until they were from nine to ten years of age, and no person has objected, but I have instructed Constable Ryckman that he is to have all children physically fit between the ages of seven and fifteen years brought into the school.

The Indians were more than pleased when they realized that Mr. Small and myself intend doing our best for the advancement of their children.

Now, Mr. Scott, under present arrangements I am unable to carry out my intentions. For example, our programme mentions that no punishment is to be given without the approval of the Principal, this was told to the Indians yesterday, but this morning this rule was entirely ignored. Now I am sorry to be obliged to say that one of the staff told me that my place was in my office.

I don't seek for my own personal satisfaction the control of the grant and the entire supervision of the school, but I maintain that the above supervision must reside in the lawful authority if we are to have harmony.

To me, it seems that I am not recognized as Principal in full charge. As long as this condition exists it will be impossible to conduct this school according to our policy enclosed.

Now, Mr. Scott, if you think well to have me replaced by another or if you wish to give the Principalship back to the Sisters, I shall be only too willing to resign, but if you insist on me retaining the position, then I shall ask you to arrange to have the school conducted on the same lines as the one in Kamloops, i.e., the Principal to have full charge.

If the above is adhered to, then the Principal will be in a position to dismiss any whom he thinks not suitable.

I may add that if I had my choice English teachers would be engaged in conducting this school.

In conclusion, if you think it better for the sake of peace and for all concerned for me to hand in my resignation I shall willingly do so.

Respectfully,

Duncan Scott, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 9th ultimo regarding the health and continued imprisonment of Damien and Jim Isaac, Indian boys of Kootenay Agency, committed to Oakalla Prison Farm, now at Vancouver General Hospital.

Damien Isaac, aged 16 years, has two years less one day at Oakalla as from October 31st, 1923. He was sent to the Vancouver General Hospital on the 30th of June for treatment for diseased glands of the neck known as cervical adenitis of tubercular origin. He is not progressing satisfactorily.

Jim Isaac, aged 16 years, was sentenced to Oakalla for two years less one day as from April 15th, 1923. He was sent to the Vancouver General Hospital June 15th, 1924, for treatment for diseased glands of the neck, secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. He is not doing well.

The low altitude, dampness, confinement and discipline with the prison food make their tubercular condition much worse. The longer they are kept here the worse their condition will become. I would therefore recommend their return to their homes as soon as it can be arranged.

The Indian boys, nominally prisoners, are really free. When the weather is fine they go out on the hospital grounds alone. There is no police surveillance at all. They are quiet and well behaved here and I feel confident they would conduct themselves properly if allowed to go home.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Kootenay Residential School, October 10th and 11, 1924.

Class-room Work.

All the teachers on the staff have English. Those in the classrooms speak good English. The standard of education is low. The pronunciation of words is not clear and distinct by the pupils. The teacher of the senior pupils is not familiar with the text books. There is a lack of thoroughness. I held a conference with the acting principal and the school teachers. There should be at least one Normal trained teacher on the staff. The standard cannot be raised in any other way.

General Remarks.

For two years there has been more or less discord among the staff. However following the appointment of the Rev. Father J. M. Smith the bickering increased. There was an entire lack of harmony. Mr Agent Small did what he could to bring about a reconciliation, but had little success. Father Smith was recalled by the Bishop.

At the time of my visit the Sisters seemed to be working together and the pupils were contented. Conditions will not be normal till a strong efficient man is found who can bring about harmony.

R. H. Cairns, Insp.
I beg to report that Jim Isaac and Damien Isaac have both arrived home from Okanagan Prison Farm.

Jim Isaac is in very poor health, but I have Dr. Coy's report today saying that he is improving. On arrival, I immediately sent him to the Shuswap Reservation where his mother will take care of him, but I fear his chances for recovery are very small.

Damien Isaac is in much better health, and he called today at the Office, and I can see a decided change in him.

I had a conversation a couple days ago with His Honour Judge Thompson with regard to Leslie Paul and Dominique, the two younger boys in the Reformatory. The Judge told me he would make a favorable report for the return to the school here of these boys. It seems their terms were forced upon His Honor by him threatening the Indians that he would not allow any more boys out on suspended sentence, unfortunately these two boys were the first to come before him, and the Judge after making the declaration had no other alternative except to carry out his threat. He, however, will be pleased to see these two boys put into the school again.

Dear Sir:

On April 2nd, 1924, an Indian boy named Louis Paul, age 14, was committed by Judge G.H. Thompson, Cranbrook, to the Industrial School for a term of 4 years on a charge of theft. At the same time another Indian boy named Joe Dominic, age 14, was committed here on a similar charge for two years. Both these boys belonged at that time to St. Eugene Mission near Cranbrook, and it appears that certain influences have been working on their behalf with the result that yesterday I received from the Under-secretary of State instructions to release these boys on condition that they return to the Kootenay Indian Residential School and should they show insubordination again, to return to finish their sentence.

You will readily understand that such things happening is not good for the discipline of a school of this kind as it looks as if an Indian boy has greater privileges than the white boy and it appears to me as if those that laid the complaint in the first place either did it with a view to scoring the boys or in order that they get free of a responsibility for the time being.

We have at present the following boys from the same school:

- Joe Skockum, Age 12, committed Apr. 2, 1924
- Joseph Casimir #15, Oct. 26, 1923,
- Pierre Jacob #15
- Alban Mike #12,

These boys are naturally resentful that the first named should be granted parole and they compelled to remain here.

I would respectfully suggest that the attention of the authorities be drawn to such a condition and ask them to be good enough to treat all alike and in future for no Indian boy to be sent here if they are of the opinion that all they require is about 6 months' attention, as the usual procedure in committing boys to this Institution is for a term of not less than two years.

Dear Father Welsh:

After having had a long talk with Father Tedrow, of St. Eugene Mission School, and receiving his assurance that you would not consider that I am interfering in private matters by writing you, I felt that it was only fair and right to let you have all the information available to me upon matters in connection with the School. I know that perhaps, some of my suggestions and remarks may not be exactly the business of the Department, except insofar as I interpret the duties of the Department officials to assist the Missionaries in their endeavours to educate the young Indian children. Strictly speaking, perhaps you might consider that I ought to simply report when things are unsatisfactory, and leave it at that, but this course of procedure does not seem very helpful to either side.

I was making my usual inspection visit of that Agency, coming in via Golden, and when attending a meeting of the Indians at the Columbia-Kootenay Reserve, I found that there were six runaway boys there. I enquired of the Agent, Mr. Small, and he informed me that this made twelve boys who had run away since the holidays, and that he was receiving endless complaints from the Indian parents, and was having endless difficulty in getting the children to school. In other words, there seemed to be a strong antipathy against the school throughout the Agency.

As you doubtless know, this is no new matter, nor is the fact of the runaways, and in 1923, I had to report the state of affairs to the Department, and go fully and frankly into the matter with the Mother Superior, informing her of exactly what the Indians had complained to me about. The complaints then, in general, were as follows:

1. The smaller boys too heavily worked;
2. Insufficient winter clothing;
3. Insufficient variable food;
4. The fact of much sickness in the school;
5. Abuse of their position by the hired help. Some of these things were rectified, and some, apparently were unfounded, and I believe, from what I hear that for a time there was not so much trouble.

However, on my visit this time, the complaints seem to have all returned even much more strongly expressed than before, accompanied with flat refusals to send the children, and statements that they, the Indians, would sooner go to prison than send their children to that school. This, as you can see, puts the Indian Department in a difficult position, as if force is used, and there is any ground for the complaints, it would, as you see, be readily taken up by those not well disposed towards the Missionaries. The only thing that I could see to do was to have the boys up in front of all the Indians and question them one by one as to their reasons for running away. This proposal met with the wishes of the Indians as well. In company with Mr. Small and an Indian interpreter, I therefore proceeded to do this. Their complaints when sifted down, were as follows:

1. Father Tedrow whipped them too much, various boys stated, from once during the term to once a day.
2. That he carried a revolver about in his pocket when whipping them, this was unanimously stated. One boy said it had been pointed at him.

Very Rev. John Welsh, O.M.I.,
Provincial of the Oblates,
NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C.
3. That they did not get sufficient food. In answer to my question they stated that they got very little milk, only in their tea or coffee, never alone; no eggs except at Easter; little meat and that sometimes bad; no oatmeal porridge; no jam; little fruit with the exception of crabapples; little butter; few fresh vegetables, and far too many potatoes. This was unanimous by all the boys.

4. That the hired men, particularly one, threatened them.

5. That they had to get up at 5:00 A.M. winter and summer.

6. The parents stated that they were insufficiently clothed and got sick at the school.

7. That the children learned nothing practical in the farming line.

The above was the gist of their complaints without mentioning names, etc., which I reported fully to Father Tedrow.

I then questioned one of the girls whom Mr. Small said was a good girl. She had no complaints at all and was happy, with the exception of not sufficient food.

As soon as I reached Cranbrook, I went straight to the School and telegraphed for Father Tedrow who was away.

In company with Mr. Small, I informed the Mother Superior of the complaints that pertained to the food, etc., but, of course, did not tell her what the boys had said of Father Tedrow, because I did not believe it, and it was his own private business. I questioned her and the sister who was cook. I found that the children were right when they stated that they had insufficient milk, also regarding the non-feeding of eggs. I found that they had only had green corn ten times throughout the season, and few green vegetables. I found that they were going to have for supper principally potatoes and a little stew for gravy left over from midday, with crabapple stew for dessert. From the taste made on the table, I found that in the larder was most distinctly bad and smell horribly, and I should judge not fit for human consumption, though the Sisters informed me that they ate it. I also found the winter supply of bottled fruits very small, not enough I should estimate, for a month's consumption. The Sister Superior informed me that they had in all 15 cows, this is to my mind, not enough, and I suggested that they get more, and more chickens.

Later, I had two long talks with Father Tedrow and with regard to the accusation of whipping and revolver work, he satisfied me that these accusations were false, as he readily believed them to be from the start. I was perfectly open with him. We then went into other matters, and Father Tedrow himself said that the hired help was not satisfactory, and that he had already written you stating that the children should have, at least, a pint of milk per diem each. He, however pointed out, that he was in somewhat of an ambiguous position at the school, which fact I had already, from observation, gathered. He informed me that the school was $800.00 behind last year.

After talking matters over with him, I could only come to one conclusion, and that was that the feeding of the children was the crux of the whole matter, and that, if that was rectified, the boys would be more contented, and there would be less sickness.
I then suggested to Father Tedrow that Mr. Small take him up to the Columbia-Kootenay reserve as soon as possible, and he could thresh matters out at a meeting which Mr. Small need not attend unless he was asked in by Father Tedrow. I wanted him to have it out with the children in the presence of the parents, without any outside influence or interference. This, the Father agreed, was the most sensible course, and he said he would go. We then talked over how we were to get round the food question without the school getting into debt. My opinions to him, which he mostly agreed with, were as follows:

1. The dual running of the school was with the best intentions between parties, not all satisfactory or workable.

2. That the school would never be a success until the farm was part and parcel of it, either from the financial, feeding or training point of view. It was absolutely necessary that a farm of about 100 acres be run entirely for the benefit of the said school, and not be a separate affair, as in that case food had to be bought at too great a cost, or dangerous cutting down of quantity and quality would result.

3. That a Missionary help outside was required as the Principal would require all his time to be devoted to the school.

4. That each boy be given a small plot of land to cultivate, and that I would recommend to the Department that a small annual prize be given, and a children's fair held in which the exhibits could be judged.

5. That the outside help could be better supervised if the farm and school were one, both under the control of the Principal.

I had in the meanwhile suggested to the Mother Superior, that in order to combat the Indian prejudice about the food, that she supply Mr. Small occasionally with a list of the meals they had given during certain weeks, and that he should often inspect the kitchen. To this she was quite agreeable.

I also pointed out to both herself and Father Tedrow that we had somehow to overcome the prejudice of the Indians in the matter, even though they might be unfounded in most cases, as there is no getting away from the fact that this antipathy is there very strongly, and that something must be wrong, as I did not meet with the same trouble elsewhere.

Since my return here, I have heard from Mr. Small that Father Tedrow had a very lengthy meeting with the Indians on the Reserve. Mr. Small understands that the boys admitted they lied about the revolver and whippings. He informs me, however, that neither he nor Father Tedrow were successful in getting the parents to allow the return of their children, though two promised to do so, by the last November. If we force them, they will only run away again, and spread the prejudice and tales.

I should like your advice on the matter. We can, of course, force them, if you think it necessary, but I myself, am inclined to think that we should move carefully, and that persuasion and a betterment of conditions should take place first.

I daresay, by this time, you have heard from Father Tedrow. I can only assure you as before that this letter is meant, not as a criticism, but as a guide, and that if you should wish to consult me or have more particulars, I am at your service.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

Acting under instructions from you I accompanied the Reverend Father Tedrow to the Columbia Kootenay Reservation, re the boys who ran away from School.

Father Tedrow spent the night with the Indians on the Reserve, and although I did not attend I understand he held a very lengthy meeting with them.

When I called for him the next morning, the Father or myself was unable to get any of the boys to return with us to the school. Dominac and Eneas Fisher, however promised me that their two boys would return on the 1st November.

I am sorry to say that they all seem to have a dislike for the Reverend Father Tedrow. Little Jim and his wife told me that they would not allow their boy to go back to the school while Father Tedrow was the Principal. This demand is unreasonable, as the boys acknowledged I understand, to Father Tedrow that they had lied both about the whipping and the revolver.

The food in the school is undoubtedly poor, and as you instructed I will in future check it up very closely. I do not know what move to make in connection with getting these boys back. I am afraid under the present conditions that if we force them to come, they will only run away again, as you understand it would be impossible for the teachers to keep them if they make up their minds to run away. I will appreciate very much your advice in the matter, and assure you that I will carry out any instructions you give me re their return.

I would advise consulting the Reverend Father Welsh in the matter, and see if he can make any suggestions, whereby we can satisfy the Indians.

I am sorry to tell you that we have a great deal of sickness in the Agency. I find this morning some ten Indians in the St. Eugene Hospital, all apparently suffering from a form of Flu or Pneumonia.

I will write you further in connection with this matter in a few days.

Your obedient servant,

Several times since the Rev. Father Lepine has taken charge of the school, he has phoned me that the above boys were making trouble in the School. On each occasion I have gone to the School, and talked to them, each time they have promised me that they would behave.

On Sunday, March the 7th Chief Adrian of the St. Mary's Band called a meeting at the School. I met him, with the principal, the Sister Superior, and about fifty Indians of the Band. The Department will find that he will put all his energy into his work at St. Eugene's and I feel sure that his appointment will be the beginning of a new era of development there.

Father Patterson is already at Cranbrook, awaiting the approval of his appointment.

I believe that you have already been informed by the Sisters of Providence that they are leaving St. Eugene's. Father Patterson will therefore be the Principal in fact as well as in name. He will take up at once the question of a new staff to replace the Sisters.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Provincial.
Ottawa, December 2, 1929.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, nominating Rev. Father J. M. Patterson, O. M. I., for the principalship of the Kootenay Indian Residential School. The Department is pleased to approve of his appointment and trusts that there will be a career of much usefulness in his case. I may say the Mother General of the Sisters of Providence has written that her Order is retiring from this institution.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Very Rev. W. Byrne Grant, O. M. I.,

Your obedient servant,

MEMO FOR FILE:

Hereunder is an inventory of all movable effects, etc., at the Kootenay Indian Residential School when the Sisters of Providence left, on or about December first, 1929. The Very Reverend Sister Amarine, Mother General of the Sisters of Providence, left this with the Department and expressed the hope that something could be done to reimburse them for equipment they had purchased. Little encouragement was given.

The Mother General also referred to the sale of some of their land to the Department and there is a special memorandum on the -9 of the file in this connection.
The tubercular condition of the children at the School and some who are now in the villages appears admittedly as a serious indictment of past administration at this School. A deplorable condition exists here, in fact, a worse condition than I have seen in my twenty-three years' experience with the Indians. I found the school a veritable tubercular institution.

My information from Reverend Principal Patterson, Constable Ryckman and Agent Small is to the effect that up to November, 1929, the school was conducted by about eleven Reverend Sisters of Charity. These all left at that time. Now Reverend Principal Patterson, O.M.I., has been in charge with other workers; that during the regime of these Sisters it was their practice to sell most of the milk and eggs and other produce in order to augment maintenance funds, disposing of these products at a rate of about $350.00 a month; that the children were given skim milk and were poorly fed; that parents were forced to put their children in the School against the protests of parents, some of whom appealed to Dr. Coy, of Invermere, to give certificates of health to support their contention that their healthy children should not be sent to the Kootenay School to be contaminated by tubercular pupils known to be in the School; that children were kept in school in an overcrowded condition until they were pronounced near to die; that 50% of the pupils now in the School are in varying stages of tuberculosis; that with the exception of about two or three children the remainder are in a predisposed condition and easy contacts; that Dr. Green, medical officer, at Cranbrook, has averred and has told Dr. Stone, of the Department, that if the physically unfit were eliminated from the School on medical examination, the school would have to be closed; that the enrolment of pupils was 74, five of whom died in one year, eight were sent back to their reserves on sick leave with tuberculosis in too advanced condition to remain in school; that there are about 25 children in the villages of whom the majority are tubercular; that there are at present 64 children in the School, and that the maximum pupilage for this School is 94.

I interviewed both Dr. Green, of Cranbrook, and Dr. Coy, of Invermere, both of whom stated the conditions to be serious at this School. Perhaps the medical reports of these doctors on file may give some details of conditions. If such reports are not on file, something...
must be wrong. For if the children are admitted as pupils in tubercular condition or are allowed to mingle with other healthy pupils in such a condition contrarily to the regulations of the Department, these responsible should be questioned regarding the matter.

I have no reason to question the veracity of the representations made to me regarding the adverse conditions at this institution, both by the local Church representatives as well as by the Department's officials in the locality of the School and medical officers having to do with the pupils. But I would advise very strongly that if the conditions are as bad as I am led to believe they are, a medical survey should be made independently of the local medical officers without delay, in order that such facts may be given the Department as may not lead to any arguments. As a layman, I do not feel competent to qualify, as a result of a brief visit to the School, statements of men who have been there for years and have watched the problem more closely, but I do feel that a medical survey would be a safe and proper course to take. This recommendation is not based upon hearsay regarding the School, but upon conditions I saw for myself whilst at the institution. On the date of my visit, May 20th, 1930, there were 61 pupils, male and female, present as resident scholars. The Principal was distressed about the condition of the children who, he alleged, had undoubtedly been neglected in the past at the School. (No doubt the reports of the late Inspector R. H. Cairns (Indian schools for B.C.) would show to what extent the farm produce was disposed of here).

The children were being given cod liver oil with their meals. A nurse was in charge of them. One long table set apart from the others accommodated pupils whose tubercular condition had been pronounced more advanced than others; and the dishes of these pupils were gathered up after each meal and washed separately from the others to avoid contagion. The other accommodations at the School were open to the children collectively. The Principal told me that everything is being done that is now possible for these children and all efforts were being concentrated upon the health of the pupils, the institution being regarded as an educational sanatorium rather than strictly a residential School.

It is recommended that action be taken in the matter of a medical survey as soon as possible as it is possible that medical officers might recommend other suitable accommodations which may be found to be essential if this School is to be put into efficient use as an establishment for the proper treatment of tubercular Indian children.

The several matters reported on herein have been fully discussed with the School authorities and with our local officials, all of whom have endorsed verbally the representations made.
The observations of Reverend Provincial Grant, O.M.I., under this head must, regretfully, be read in the light of the preceding paragraphs of this report which qualify the assertions made in regard to the alleged malnutrition of the children of the Reserves.

The children must necessarily suffer to some extent on account of such conditions, added to the proverbial lack of the instinct of self-preservation which marks the progress of some Indian families. But this suffering does not appear to have been ameliorated to any great extent by the admitted lack of sustenance and attention given the pupils within the School, from a health standpoint, and it is therefore thought that the source of malnutrition may not be wholly traced to the Reserves.

EXTRACTS FROM DR. STORE'S REPORT

on
KOOTENAY INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

PUPILS:

The children look particularly well nourished. Independent observers told me that the change in this respect in the last year is phenomenal. They appear really fond of the principal and staff. The absence of restraint and fear is most gratifying. There is practically no truancy now. They are well dressed, but I have seen cleaner looking clothes. Perhaps better laundry facilities would remedy this apparent defect. The oldest pupil, with one exception, is under 17 years old. I was told that there are no mental deficient among them and no chronic bed-wetters.

There ought to be 100 children of school age in the agency. There are 69 in the school and not more than 4 or 5 not in.

Tuberculosis:

While present conditions are not as bad as anticipated, they are bad enough. Five pupils died of tuberculosis between Nov. 1929, and June, 1930 - none since - and none died after discharge and not accounted for above. Dr. A. S. Lamb, Provincial Travelling Diagnostician, has just completed a survey of the pupils - 10 - 12 have active tuberculosis and are potential dangers to the well. A further 10 or 12 are suspects but are not considered active at present nor dangerous to others. I should say that this latter group are more likely to improve than otherwise and may be left out of the calculation, unless they show fever or loss of weight.

After looking over conditions from all angles and after exhaustive discussion with Dr. Lamb, the Principal and Matron, the Indian Agent (Hyckman) and the local Dr., (Green), I came to the following conclusions, which are concurred in by Dr. Lamb:

1. That it would not be advisable to discharge these tuberculous pupils to their homes, from the standpoint of the pupils or the families.

2. That there are facilities at the school and that the staff may be relied upon to provide reasonable effective measures for taking care of them at the school without turning it into a sanatorium or seriously disturbing its present arrangement.

3. That it will require more effective medical oversight than has been furnished in the past. Dr. Lamb makes semi-annual visits to Cranbrook.
PUPILS:

Tuberculosis (continued)

and has undertaken to check up the pupils on each visit, to the extent of going over the ones known to be tuberculous, and any new suspects. I had a serious talk with Dr. Green. He is known given to understatement, but is known to be very competent. I think he will give the necessary attention, both general and detailed. Dr. Lamb has undertaken to prescribe rules for separation of the tuberculous from the well. I went so far as to say to Dr. Green that the Dept. was very serious about this matter and was willing to pay for the amount of attention required for success but in any event wanted service. I think that the most likely source of defect is the danger of the Principal and Matron, who are pretty self-confident, undertaking measures without adequate direction. This will bear a little watching.

4. That some of the 12 or 12 known cases may be expected to fail and die. I expressed the view that these should not be sent home, particularly if there are younger children in the families. The school ought not to have, nor to try, to care for them after they break down, and I recommended that they be put in the Cranbrook hospital, unless the parents positively demanded their return home.

5. I directed that, until further orders, no child be admitted to the school, unless certified free from serious suspicion of active tuberculosis after the most careful examination available.

6. That, as a minimum measure of special assistance, the Department should pay the salary of a graduate nurse - $960 - ($1200). So long as the present nurse-matron remains and proves satisfactory, this will serve to pay her salary. Should a change be made, we should put in our own nurse.

In August 1930 I was removed from my position as engineer at the Kootenay Indian School, Cranbrook B.C. by the principal Mr. Patterson. At that time the school had just supplied new parts to the value of about $400 for the repair of the engine and they also contemplated supplying new batteries to cost about $300.

Mr. Patterson produced a letter from the Indian Dept stating that on account of the expense they incurred in overhauling the lighting plant they found it necessary to insist on a qualified engineer being
employed. Having read the letter he dealt at length on the necessity of having a responsible person in charge, particularly on account of the new batteries. He also stated that the Dept intended to pay a special grant for a qualified engineer. He asked me if I had the required qualification. I replied that I had sufficient qualifications to satisfy the requirements, but when I attempted to produce evidence of them he prevented me from doing so.

He had employed Mr. Miles as carpenter a short time previously. This man represented himself as a qualified engineer from the University of Saskatchewan and he was given the position from that date.

Later I had an interview with the Secretary Dept of Indian Affairs at Victoria in connection with this matter. He denied that any such letter was ever issued, neither did they ever raise any question about the engineer's qualifications nor did they make any statement about a grant towards the engineer's salary. The evidence of qualification which I produced was perfectly satisfactory. I also had a letter from the Registrar Univ of Saskatchewan, showing that this Mr. Miles was unknown to them and that he had never been a student, or taken work at any time at the University. The secretary at Victoria said there was a possibility that this letter came from Ottawa, or from the Indian agent. I think the Indian agent is out of the question, he would hardly assume responsibility for such statements, and I think also that the matters dealt with in the "letter" would be outside his duties.

I have taken up this matter with Mr. Patterson, but he is unable to give any satisfactory
explanation or to account for the "letter."

Therefore I am writing to ask if the letter originated at Ottawa and if so I would like to have a copy at your convenience.

I remain,

Yours Truly,

P. Byrne.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a letter received from the Reverend J. M. Patterson, Principal of Kootenay Indian Residential School, in which he makes application to have the school quota raised to ninety.

I beg to submit that before the Reverend Patterson took charge of this school there were numerous cases of truancy and of crimes and misdemeanors committed by these truants. Nearly every child had to be forced to attend school, and at the close of vacation and also at other times there was a great deal of expense bringing the pupils from their Reserves to school. In the past three years there has been no truancy whatever and the parents and relatives have brought their children to school at little or no expense to the Department, and in all cases they have been brought of their own free will.

In addition to bringing about a most decided change for the better at the school, the Reverend Principal has been of the greatest assistance in promoting order and decency on the Reserves, and I appreciate this assistance more than I can say. We now have the confidence of the Indians and are, for the first time in many years, in a position to work out plans for the improvement of the Reserves, and while it must of necessity take time to work out our plans, I feel quite confident that if we are permitted to continue as at present there will be a very decided change for the better on all the Reserves in this Agency in a few years.

It is for the above reasons that I beg to strongly recommend to the consideration of the Department the enclosed letter from the Reverend Principal. I sincerely trust that as a real aid in furthering our plans for the betterment of the Reserves his application for an increase in the school quota may be looked upon with favour.

The above is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report that when I visited Kootenay Residential School yesterday evening, on my way to Cherry Creek to attend to the automatic water gauge, I learned that arrangements had already been made to transfer the Reverend J. M. Patterson and that another member of the Oblate Order was expected to reach here in a very few days to take his place as Principal of the school. I accordingly sent the following night lettergram to the Department on my return to Cranbrook shortly after midnight:

"I have learned that Reverend Patterson to be transferred and new Principal appointed his place immediately STOP Believe it of vital importance to Department that no change be made at present STOP Will Department please take matter up with head of Oblate Order and have action postponed until letter reaches Ottawa."

I beg to submit that I am convinced that this proposed change is of the greatest importance to this Agency, and I feel it is only fair to all concerned that I explain to the Department the conditions at the school as fully as possible.

As the Department is aware, I have been in fairly close touch with Kootenay Residential School for nearly twenty-three years. For some eighteen years it was my duty to act as Truant Officer, which necessitated almost constant contact with the pupils, the teachers, and those in charge. I do not wish to speak disparagingly of anyone, but I saw conditions at the school during those years and I am quite sure that of the numerous complaints made the majority were not without foundation. There were a number of Principals, some of them very able ones, who tried to bring about an improvement at the school during that time but none met with success, and complaints from Indians and whites of poor food, too much work, tuberculosis and other sickness among the pupils, etc., continued to be heard on every hand.

When the Reverend J. M. Patterson took over the school late in 1929 conditions generally were so bad that it was doubtful if it could be kept running much longer. Of the fifty odd pupils in the building practically all were tubercular, and when Dr. F. W. Green examined them he stated that there were only a few of the total number who did not show unmistakable signs of the disease, and that he would not say that any were entirely free from it. Both the Doctor, the Nurses and the new Principal stated that the children were all under nourished and in very poor physical condition.

One of the first acts of the Reverend Patterson was to engage a Trained Nurse and turn the school into what was actually a tubercular sanitarium, as he realized that the health of the pupils must be restored, at least in part, and their bodies built up before progress in their various studies would be possible. Since that time all food used in the school has been prescribed by a Trained

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
a Trained Nurse, a very close watch has been kept over the pupils and those showing the least sign of illness have received prompt attention. Machines have been installed to do the heavy work formerly done by the boys, such as sawing and splitting wood, etc., and the heavier farm and house work is all done by hired help, either adult Indians or whites. The food regularly placed on the tables is much better than in the average home of white people, and the result is that the pupils are much better nourished than they have been in the history of the school and are making better progress with their studies. Formerly children had to be forced to attend school and truancy was common among them, but in nearly six years not one child has been forced to attend and there has been but one case of truancy, that of a sub-normal boy.

The effect on the school has been great, but the effect on the Indians of the various Reserves has been even greater. Due to causes too numerous to mention at this time the Indians, with but few exceptions, had almost entirely lost faith in the school, the Church, and practically everything pertaining to law and order, and both the Reverend Principal and myself realized that until that faith was restored little or no progress could be made. That has now been accomplished, and I believe a larger share of the credit is certainly due to the Reverend Father Patterson. I am quite convinced that since the first Principal of the school left this district no Priest has had such control over the Indians as the Reverend Principal now has, and to move him from this Agency before our plans have been properly worked out would mean, without doubt, a return to their former state within a very few years.

I realize that the financial condition of the School has not been at all good during the past few years, and in fairness to the Reverend Principal and the Department I feel that I should now report on this matter exactly as I see it, for it is my belief that finances, or rather lack of finances, is the real cause of the proposed change.

When the Reverend Patterson took charge of the school he also took over debts left by the former Principals amounting to some five thousand dollars. In 1930 the average number of pupils was only 59, in 1931 it was 67, the following year 70, in 1933 the average increased to 73, in 1934 to 80, and the present year to approximately 90 pupils. The school can not pay its way with less than about 85 pupils and maintain the present standard. I understand that prior to 1930 certain sums of money were owed in to the Oblate Order by the Principals each year, but because of the small number of pupils and the fact that so many were ill, it has been impossible to put this end, at the same time, keep out of debt and build up the school. The Department has done everything possible to assist, and the Reverend Principal has certainly done heroic work; but under the circumstances I think it very unfair of the Oblate Order to expect the Reverend Principal to pay debts contracted by his predecessors. As already mentioned, I have been in very close touch with the school and I am perfectly certain there has been no mismanagement and no extravagance. The Reverend Principal has not had, during his term of office, any proper assistance from the Oblate Order, but has had to run the school, the farm, the Missions, and the financial end of it alone. I am quite sure that if he had an experienced Priest to keep the books and look after office matters generally, and also make visits to the Reserves when necessary it would be of the greatest assistance.
Until about three years ago the large farm owned by the Oblate Order was leased to Chinese, and as very little feed can be raised on the school farm the Reverend Principal was forced to buy some fifteen hundred dollars worth of feed each year, but since the farm has been taken over by him and properly cared for there has been no shortage of feed or garden truck. The school has been on a paying basis since the first of this year, but it is impossible to discharge the old debts.

The Reverend Principal has carried on the Missionary work on all Reserves in the Agency, and has also controlled the social work, which is, I believe, an entirely new departure in Roman Catholic schools in this Province, for in other Agencies the Missionaries are separate from the Principals. The present arrangement keeps the Indians in closer contact with the school, which is absolutely necessary in this Agency.

For confirmation of the above I would respectfully refer the Department to the Archbishop of the Oblate Order in B.C. at Vancouver.

In closing, Sir, may I respectfully request that this matter be placed before the Deputy Superintendent General for his consideration. It is my belief that it is of vital importance to this Agency and to the Department that the Reverend Father Patterson continue as Principal of Kootenay Residential School for at least a few years more, and I sincerely trust that the Department will use their influence with the head of the Oblate Order to have this brought about. I am quite sure that they are not at all familiar with the true situation here or the move would not even be considered.

The above is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman,

Kootenay Indian Residential School

It was indeed a pleasure to welcome Captain Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, who, in response to a somewhat urgent request from a number of St Mary's Indians, kindly consented to make his annual inspection a few days earlier than he had otherwise planned.
