Indian Residential School Reopens With Enrolment of 90

(From Our Own Correspondent)

CRANBROOK, Sept. 11. — The Indian residential school, which provides for the education of Indian children of the interior of the province, reopened its doors last week with an enrolment of about 90 children from seven to 16 years from the Shuswap, Kootenay and Okanagan tribes.

These children receive the same basic education given in public schools throughout the province with amendments to suit special needs. For health reasons the pupils have only a half school-day in classes, while the other half is devoted to practical outdoor education. In addition, sanitation is given including treatment for trachoma and sound training in tuberculosis prevention. The school has a small preventorium.

Practical education includes farming, manual training, carpentry, animal husbandry, cooking, sewing, dairy work and beadwork. A music course is also popular.

The children help in the maintenance of their own residential buildings and the Department of Indian Affairs pays a daily grant on the basis of each child.

Practically self-sustaining, the school and the nearby farm run by the Oblate Fathers raise their own vegetables, beef, supply their own milk, cream and butter.

Father G. Forbes, B.A., M.A., principal, and Rev. F. Sheppard, disciplinarian for boys, with three male instructors for the boys' practical courses, while seven Sisters of Charity of Halifax are assigned the school as teachers, nurses and housekeepers. A first aid course given by the nurse was started this year.

Principal aim of the school is to prepare the young ones for becoming self-supporting citizens in the case of the boys, and the care of homes for the girls, with maintenance of sound health a dominant factor.
REPORT ON KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OCTOBER, 1943.

School:

The Kootenay Indian Residential School has again settled down to its regular routine. On the occasion of my recent visit the Dormitories, Preventorium, Class rooms, dining room, kitchen, pantry etc. were all spotlessly clean and the excellent spreads on the Dining room tables was proof conclusive that the children are not being stinted for food, on the contrary they are being well supplied with the necessary varieties of healthy, nourishing and appetizing things to eat.

The three run-away girls mentioned in my last report have since returned to school. They were picked up at McLeod, Alta. by a R.C.M. Police, and escorted back to Cranbrook by a priest.

The three young boys who were mentioned in my last report as having run away from school tried it again this month. The weather, however, was uncomfortably cold so much so that one little lad returned to the school of his own accord before completing his first night out. The other two were located and brought back the following day.

Main Roof repair work undertaken at the School by the Firm of Patmore Bros., in which only Tremco products were used has been in as far as one can tell at the present time satisfactorily completed. The job appears to have been well done, and it is not thought possible that further trouble in this connection will be experienced for many years to come.

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.

INSPECTION REPORT
KOOTENAY INDIAN AGENCY
January 26th to February 23rd, 1944.

KOOTENAY I.R.A. No. 1 (St. Mary's) 1735 acres. Population 161.

No routine inspection was made of this Reserve as it was in the midst of winter and time did not permit more than a cursory examination of it. The following are notes of those details discussed with the Agent.

HEALTH:

The incidence of T.B. appears to have been high and accounted for most of the high death rate in the past and probably a large contributing factor to the altogether unnecessarily high infant mortality. I suspect that the maternal affection of this group is below that of Indians elsewhere in the Province.

At one time good work was done by the Rev. Sisters - Nurse at the Residential School, but the small monthly grant of $20.00 for her services as dispenser was discontinued in March or April 1941. Sister Marion Clair, a graduate of Massachusetts General appears to be a very intelligent and devoted woman, and I am of the opinion that we are overlooking a good opportunity in not employing her on a part time basis at a salary of $25.00 per month, plus a limited car mileage, to visit Indian homes on this Reserve and carry out an active anti-tuberculosis programme in addition to the work usually devolving upon a field matron, particularly on such subjects as pre-natal and postnatal care and child welfare. She has, of course, visited cases of urgency when called or became aware of the need, but what is required is regular visitation with encouragement of providing better homes and cultivation of gardens from a health point of view. The Rev. Principal understands that the nurse was included in the school staff at the request of Doctor Stone who agreed to pay the cost of her salary and that the Department's files will show this. However, the suggestion here is not in respect to her services in the school with the children, although undoubtedly they result in a considerable saving of hospitalization to the Department, but to her part time employment among the Indians of St. Mary's Reserve.

J. Cohenan, Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am now in a position to advise you that Reverend Father Forbes is leaving Cranbrook Indian School. For some time past his health has not been at all strong. During the many years he has been associated with Indian work he has certainly devoted himself whole heartedly to those under his care.

Acting on the suggestion of the Inspector of the School I have looked around in order to find a Principal who who would have a thorough practical knowledge of farming. I am, therefore, submitting to the Department the name of Reverend Father Gerald Kelly to succeed Father Forbes as Principal. Father Kelly has had many years of agricultural experience, and amongst other positions has held the office of Bursar in our Establishment on the Montreal Road. I do not anticipate any difficulty on his part in adapting himself to his new surroundings. When speaking to Mr. Hoey some time ago, I mentioned the possibility of this change, and he did not see any objection to Father Kelly's appointment.

With my kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

J. Scannell

I have your letter of August 20th advising that Reverend Father Forbes is giving up his duties as Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School and will shortly be succeeded by Reverend Gerald Kelly, O.M.I.

Reverend Father Forbes is held in the highest esteem by the officials of the Department here, and it is with genuine regret that we learn that he contemplates giving up the work at Cranbrook.

I may say that I have known Father Forbes for many years, having first come in contact with him when he was Principal of the Cariboo Indian Residential School. His kindly and sympathetic interest in the Indian people has won for him a lasting place in their affections. No one could have worked harder or more devotedly on their behalf and I am sure that many of them will learn with real sadness of his withdrawal from the work in which he was so active on their behalf. As is unavoidable in an administration such as ours, differences of opinion regarding certain matters arose from time to time, but these have not lessened in any way the great regard in which he has been held by the Commissioner and other officials of this staff.

I wish to assure you that this office will extend to the new Principal every possible assistance in the task to which he has been called.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: St. Eugene Indian Residential School, Cranbrook

Among the matters brought to my attention by Reverend Principal Kelly when I visited the above-noted school last month was the difficulty the institution continued to experience in meeting the costs of operation. I am inclined to think that this situation is partly due to the small grant-earning income of the school.

At the time of my visit there were seven children in the school in excess of the grant-earning pupilage and I was informed that there were twelve others not attending any school who should be admitted. An increase of ten in the number of pupils for whom the grant is authorized would greatly assist this school financially and as accommodation for at least this additional number can be provided, seven of whom are already in the school, it is felt that the Department would be justified in approving this increase.

I may say that I was very favourably impressed with the new principal, Reverend Gerald Kelly. He is a keen, young, active man and has already shown evidence of having taken a firm hold on the administration of the school. He will, I am sure, measure up well to the heavy responsibilities of the Principalship.

The school is badly run down and consequently much is needed by way of repairs and improvements. I advised Father Kelly that the work required could not all be attended to at once, but that we would do all in our power to assist in having the most urgent items attended to as quickly as the necessary funds could be secured.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

I beg to submit that in this report I have endeavoured to show that a certain amount of progress has been made by the Indians of this Agency in the past six months, but it is difficult to explain the marked change in the attitude of the Indians toward the school, the Department and this office, and law and order. Welfare and Training:

The Kootenay Indian School under the efficient leadership of Reverend Gerald Kelly, O.M.I., has made very steady progress during this quarter. The pupils are making rapid progress in their class room studies, domestic science, and manual training. The tubercular patients have shown very satisfactory improvements. There has been little or no sickness in school during this quarter except for five cases of measles, one reported on December 17th and four on December 29th. Antimesles serum was used on the contacts and it is hoped that this epidemic will reach no great proportions. The pupils are well nourished and their health is carefully looked after by Sister Marion Clare. The pupils were vaccinated against smallpox and will be vaccinated against typhoid as soon as the measles is over. The school is well supplied with milk, eggs, vegetables and fruit.

This school carries eight pupils in excess of its quota. Three Auld children, who do not belong to the reserves, will be returned home as soon as the quarantine on measles permits, however, this still leaves us short of space for twelve pupils from the Columbia lake and Shuswap Reserves who should be returned to school, not only for their own good but as a matter of discipline. This matter has been referred to the Department and I am awaiting a reply before taking any action.

The fire extinguishers requisitioned for the school were finally received, and fire drills are held as per regulations. One unscheduled rehearsal was held at 5:00 o'clock one morning when the new fireman and night watchman inadvertently pulled the fire alarm. This proved to be a good and successful fire drill. In addition to the night watchman and fireman, Rev. Father Kelly has hired a new farm manager, who has good recommendations.

On my last inspection it was noted that good work had been done in re-decorating the girls play room, several chairs having successfully been re-upholstered with bright materials. Kindergarten tables and temporary chairs as well as other objects have been whitewashed in the Manual Training department. The domestic science department does excellent work in cooking under the direction of Sister John Anthony and Sister Catherine Mary's sewing class produced very good work. The pantry and hallway near the Father's dining room has also been redecorated.

The situation with reference to the plumbing at the school is still bad, even though some of the toilets were temporarily repaired, flush actions, etc. are so far unobtainable. One urinal near the boys dormitory was put in working order and all taps were replaced.

Welfare & Training:

At the Kootenay Indian School continued progress is being made both in and out of the classroom. The children are well cared for and have an excellent record of health. A number of replacements have been procured for worn out beds in both the boys' and girls' dormitories. A program of cleaning and painting in the lavatories and several changes in plumbing have made for better hygiene, but a continued project for redecoration of the basement passages is urgently needed. Because it was found impossible to procure replacement parts, the toilets on both sides of the school are still awaiting repairs to seats and flush actions.

The school is carrying several pupils above its dormitory quota, but more pupils could be accommodated comfortably if some small low-cost changes were effected. This would make possible acceptance of a number of school age children from Columbia Lake and Shuswap Reserves upon whose parents pressure is being applied to have them send their children to school.

Much trouble has been experienced in recent weeks with lighting and pumping equipment at the school. A series of breakdowns has necessitated repairs to all three power units, overhaul of the emergency 4 k.w. diesel generator, replacement of water pump and batteries, at considerable cost to the Department and to the discomfort and inconvenience to the residents of the school. The Principal and many of the staff laboured for days with some outside help to restore services to normal. From time to time representations have been made to the Department to have an installation made, connecting the school to the West Kootenay Power Line some two miles distant. Welfare and Training:

The Reverend Gerald Kelly, O.M.I., and his staff have done excellent work during this past quarter at our Kootenay Indian Residential School, but much remains to be done before this school can be brought to a high standard of efficiency.

Utilities in general continue to be the greatest problem. A new hydro pressure tank has been procured to replace the worn out domestic water supply tank, but due to extreme weather conditions prevailing at this time, it is impractical to have this tank installed until spring. The extreme hardness of the present water supply has proven costly in water softeners, replacing heating coils, and generally impairs the efficiency of all heating equipment. It is hoped that replacement of the worn out soft water supply line from St. Joseph's Creek can be started in the near future. Although this water is unfit for domestic purposes, it would give a good supply of soft water for general purposes as well as a much needed additional supply for fire protection.

A Mr. McKinnon has been engaged to instruct the classes in manual training. This man has had considerable experience in this type of teaching and it is hoped that progress will be made after the commencement of school January 6th. This vocational training department has made little or no progress since the opening of school last fall due to the inability of procuring a suitable instructor.

Installation of drinking fountains in the dairy barn have been completed and will undoubtedly prove their worth in higher milk production.

Light and power facilities are performing well, but are inadequate and a considerable course of work and worry for the attendants and it is to be hoped that arrangements will one day be made for the acquisition of hydro power facilities, this in itself would form the groundwork for an efficient
Considerable difficulty was occasioned in persuading the parents of tardy pupils in sending their children to the school. This aversion seems to have disappeared and Indians who at the beginning of the term were completely immune to any kind of persuasion have voluntarily brought their children in.

With 99 (ninety-nine) pupils on the roll, the school is comfortably filled. The children all appear much happier than when they first arrived for the fall term; their work in the classrooms has improved, particularly in drawing and painting, writing and arithmetic. The new system instigated this fall whereby the two junior grades receive full time instruction has shown marked improvement over the work done in these two grades in previous years. Another plan for improvement also shows results. This plan is fulfilled in a study period every evening for all classes. Four of the more advanced pupils are now taking grade nine work from grade nine curriculum and their teacher reports fine progress, especially in English and Mathematics.

Another fine improvement appeared at the school over the Christmas holidays in the form of a new 16 m.m. sound and moving picture projector. Two good films and a short were procured for the holiday season and school children and parents alike turned out in full force at every showing. The school has obtained access to the local National Film Board Library here in Cranbrook and have applied to the Visual Instruction Service at University of B.C. for educational films.

At the time of my last visit to the school, the children were happily engaged in winter sports, the skating rinks and toboggan slides were in full swing. The school itself was decorated in festive apparel from attic to basement. These decorations were truly artistic and were a credit to the supervisors and proof of the artistic temperament of the Indian children.

Altogether the morale of the school shows a decided improvement from the time of my last quarterly report and Father Kelly has shown great perseverance with considerable success in overcoming parental distrust and aversion to the school, and, despite a woeful lack of funds, continues to lay plans for future improvement.

"Residential School

The Kootenay Indian Residential School under the capable leadership of the Reverend G.F. Kelly O.M.I. continues to provide satisfactory services to the welfare and education of the Indian children in their care. The spirit of the staff and the attitude of pupils and parents alike is commendable. Several of the parents made a special trip to the office to remark on their satisfaction of the fine progress of their children during the past term.

The additional classroom provided this past term has relieved the overcrowding and has been used to fine advantage by the staff in their program of increased hours of tuition to the pupils.

Of seven pupils that have been recommended to High School since September 1947 only four are at present continuing their education. Two are taking grade ten and two are in grade nine at the Cranbrook High School. Their progress is not outstanding but has been reported as entirely satisfactory.

A full quota of supplies for the Manual Training and Domestic Science classes has been supplied by the Dept., as well as a fine array of sporting equipment. A good fall of snow plus extreme cold weather finds the two outdoor skating rinks and toboggan slide in fine condition and swarming with the pupils and staff alike at every opportunity.

The main pipeline to replace the old line that supplied the school with soft water from St. Joseph's creek was laid this past quarter; due to extreme weather conditions prevailing it was impossible to complete all connections and completion of this project had to be deferred until next spring.

The main school building has received two coats of paint on all exterior trim, all cracks in the cement and stonework have been sealed with caulking compound. The completion of this big project gives great satisfaction to the Reverend Principal and myself and needless to say it will prolong the life as well as it has greatly improved the appearance of this fine structure.

Our inability to procure the services of a qualified Instructor for the Manual Training class is regretted. The vital importance of this branch of education is fully realized but at present the only instruction the boys are receiving is obtained through assisting with general maintenance of the school property."
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I respectfully submit the following report on the general administration of this Kootenay Indian Agency for the quarter ended March 31st, 1949, having endeavoured to cover all points of interest vital to the Kootenay Indians and to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Education.

By popular request the St. Patrick's Day School Concert was repeated before an overflow audience at the St. Mary's Hall, here in Cranbrook. With a cast of fifty-two girls and boys a one hour and a half programme of Irish songs, skits and a one act play surprised and pleased an appreciative audience. The Rev. Principal and his staff are to be commended on the costumes and continuity of this fine performance which provides the local public schools with a goal they will find difficult to equal. Their first appearance in a role of this magnitude the Indian children behaved like veterans and enjoyed every moment on the stage.

(Sgd) J. S. Dunn,
Superintendent.

With reference to your letter of June 8th, 1949, in connection with an enrollment of 110 pupils at our Kootenay Indian Residential School when the authorized pupilage, under the rule of 500 cubic feet of dormitory air space per pupil would apparently limit an authorized pupilage of 100.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April 22nd, 1933, file No. 155-0-3, with reference to a request made by the Reverend J. M. Patterson, Principal of Kootenay Indian Residential School, for an advance of $1200.00 on the June quarterly grant.

I beg to submit that the Reverend Principal informed me today that he had not yet received the balance of about $1300.00 due on the March quarter, and requested me to ask if the cheque had been forwarded, for if so it has no doubt gone astray. As the Reverend Principal has some payments to make within a very few days and is badly in need of funds, if the cheque has not been forwarded will the Department please wire the amount to him in care of the Canadian Bank of Commerce at Cranbrook.

I also beg to suggest that if an advance can be made on the June quarter when funds are available it will be of great assistance to the Reverend Principal. For the information of the Department I beg to state that when the Reverend Patterson took over the management of the school he found it rather heavily in debt, and this has made it very difficult for him to meet his obligations.

Respectfully submitted,

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

F. S. Ryckman,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication from the Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School requesting an advance of $1,000 on the September quarter grant.

In this connection I have to say that it will not be possible to forward this advance until early in August, next. Regulations of the Treasury Board do not permit making advances before the grant is earned. I may add, however, that a cheque will go forward in the near future for the balance of the grant due for the quarter ended June 30th, last.

The Department has had considerable correspondence regarding outstanding accounts owed by the Principal. This matter has been referred to the Provincial of the Oblate Order. Dear Mr. Helen:

If it is convenient for you to do so, I would appreciate your having $1500 of the grant for the present quarter paid to me as early in July as possible. I would like to pay off all outstanding bills & $1500 plus the $360 owed by the Indians will enable me to do so.

I wish to take this opportunity to thank the Department for the $800 of flooring, the papers & nails, which have already come, and also for the tools & material for a Carpenter Shop which are to come.

Mr. Commissioner MacKay was here recently. From what I have heard, the local Indians are pleased with his visit. Most of them are making good use of the irrigation system and I expect that they will continue to do so. I am convinced that irrigation was impracticable & disastrous without irrigation.

With kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

G. Foster

P.S. The holidays start on the 24th. All pupils are well. G.J.

Kootenay Indian School
Cranbrook, B.C.

Mr. Philip Shelan,
Chief Training Division,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Shelan:

Would you please have about $150.00 of the March per capita grant sent to me as I have less than $90.00 in the Bank & this would pay the Indians for the wood I am buying from them let alone cover February bills.

I did not believe it necessary to reply to the letter in which you said that you hoped that we were again competing in the TB Contest - he started on a right after the Material came - I fear, however, that "Compete" is hardly the word. Still, no idea is being implanted: One of our younger girls told her aunt, a few days ago, why she should stop her baby from crawling on the floor, etc.

You may recall that, after you had told me that Mr. Inspector Fredrickson had reported to you that he had been informed that he had no...
ceived only six books per annum, I told you that I knew nothing of Mr. Walter. Since then, I have learned who made the report to him. According to Mr. Simpson, only six books were sent in the year referred to.

Mr. Fredericksen has just spent 3 days here. He appears rather pleased with certain improvements in the teaching methods but notes room for further improvement.

Yours sincerely,

C. J. [signature]

Mr. Phalen, Director of Indian Education,

Dear Mr. Phalen:

A short time ago I sent a letter to your division of the Dept., asking for an advance on the June-Sept. Grant. As I was not sure if you had returned from the West I did not address it to you.

Would you be kind enough to check on my letter to see if it was received and if the requested advance of two thousand has been sent. To date I have not received any reply.

Mr. Arneil told me early in August that you were expected at the coast. I am sorry you did not have time to visit us here but no doubt your time was limited.

Our school year is again under way with an enrolment of a hundred and three. All the children of this Agency who are of school age are enrolled so we are off to a good start.

Trusting you can arrange the requested advance and with sincere thanks,

I remain,

Truly Yours,

G.F. Kelly O.M.I.,
Principal.

Reverend G. Kelly, O.M.I.,

Dear Father Kelly:

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, I am advised by the Treasury that the advance of $2,000 on your September per capita grant has gone forward and no doubt has reached you by this time.

I was sorry that I could not visit your school. As a matter of fact, I was on my holidays and not on official Government business and I was only able to spend three days in British Columbia. I am glad to know that you have a full enrolment and hope that you will have another successful year.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Mr. Phalen:

If possible I would like to arrange an advance of twenty-five hundred on the October-December Quarter. This will enable me to meet some outstanding accounts before the end of the calendar year.

I do not like putting your Dept. to the inconvenience of advance payments but I am finding it increasingly difficult to keep out of the "red" with the continued rise in the prices of food, clothing, and labor. This has been particularly evident since the opening of the Fall Term. I hope there is the possibility of an increase in grant or the salary payment schedule being put into effect in the near future. If not I'm afraid we are going to end this year with a considerable deficit. The demand for better food, clothing, and living conditions for the children just can't be met on the present grant.

Sir,

Enclosed herewith please find two pay-rolls certified by the Reverend Father Smith and the Reverend Sister Superior.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

CRANBROOK, B.C., March 5, 1925

Department of Indian Affairs

Gentlemen,

On Dec. the 30th I presented my bill for work done at the Industrial School here to Mr. Small the Indian Agent. There where two bills one for $200.00 and one for $25.00. Up to now I have not received payment for this work. On previous occasion I have always received payment within the month. I am thinking that perhaps the bills or even the checks if same have been made out may have miscarried and I beg you to investigate this matter and oblige.

Yours respectfully,

Alfred Lebeau
Ottawa, March 11th, 1925.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 5th instant, I beg to say that your account of $200.00 therein referred to was paid by cheque No. 5908 on the 23rd February, upon which date the cheque went forward to you at Cranbrook. It was drawn in favour of the Economy Plumbing & Heating Company.

I may add that seemingly your account of $25.00 has not reached the Department. It is advisable for you to communicate in the matter with the Indian Agent, Mr. Small, of Cranbrook.

Yours truly,

[F.H. Paget]
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

Economy Plumbing and Heating Co.,
Cranbrook, B.C.

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Gentlemen,

I beg to report that one check of $200.00 had arrived for which I thank you.

Yours respectfully,

A. Lebeau
Ottawa, April 2, 1925.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of voucher No.839 rendered at $11.65 which you submitted in favour of the Cranbrook Drug & Book Company, Limited, of Cranbrook, and in reply I may say that the said voucher has been paid at $5.50, which payment covers supplies furnished the Indian School. The charges in the voucher for office supplies and for drugs should be made out on separate accounts as expenditure for schools should not at any time be included in a voucher in which other charges are made.

With regard to the drugs supplied, I may say you should explain why the Indian who received the same did not pay for them. All accounts for drugs supplied on a prescription should be certified to by the doctor who wrote the prescription, but in this connection I have to remind you that all doctors employed by the Department are not allowed to charge for drugs. Some of them who are on salary should furnish medicines without charge, and you should be particular, therefore, with regard to all accounts for medicines which you transmit to the Department.

When you deal with the foregoing matter you should submit the vouchers under cover of a letter of explanation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Dear Sir:

I acknowledge with gratitude the purposeful and helpful interest which you have shown in our school in the past. With this in mind, I have no fear in being disappointed when I find myself obliged to solicit your interest again in a matter of some importance.

I think you will agree that I have now occupied my position long enough to be able to say with tolerable exactness what are the most keenly felt needs of our School. While some of these regard the main building and the outbuildings, I consider that the most pressing are those which concern the health, the moral and physical upbringing of the children. I wish to call your attention to the lack of all adequate playground facilities.

It is generally admitted that wholesome recreation is an integral part of all school-life, a fundamental feature in any sound system of education. Besides greatly increasing the prestige of an educational institution, it is as a factor itself in education that the chief usefulness of sport and athletics lies.

Their physical value is unquestionable. They inculcate care of the body, the development of healthy habits, and induce habits of energizing vitality. Nor is their moral value to be underrated. Well-directed exercise breeds characteristics of vigor, mental keenness and stimulate to greater effort in the class-room. These are qualities which you will recognize are much to be desired in our Indians.

Our Children have been at a disadvantage in this respect. And it may be easily seen that we cannot deprive childhood of its heritage of play without paying the price in stultified youth and unenergetic maturity. The distressing cases of delinquency which have occurred here in the past, I believe I may attribute at least in great part, to a lack of recreational activity. Where wholesome diversion is not provided for the child, he will seek it himself, wholesome or otherwise. And the forming of cliques, the brooding habit, the discontent which this inactivity engenders, is detrimental to the highest influence of the School.
We are doing our best to face this difficulty. We have enlarged and improved their playgrounds. But we find that the expense of equipping them with durable apparatus, to provide the boys with athletic goods, is beyond our means. We, therefore, appeal to the Department to defray the cost of the following:

1. A play shed for the girls to be built by the boys under the supervision of Mr. Morris, their Instructor of Manual training.

2. The apparatus called the "Ocean Wave" and also the one called the "Giant Strides".

3. An outdoor gymnastic outfit for the boys.

4. Two basket ball outfits, one for the boys and one for the girls.

5. A baseball outfit and a football outfit.

6. One vaulting pole.

Trusting that this demand will not be deemed excessive, I am Sir,

Yours respectfully,

(sgd) F.W. Tedrow O.M.I.
Principal.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing copy of communication from the Rev. Principal of the Kootenay Indian Residential School relative to playground equipment for the pupils. The Department agrees that each residential school should have equipment of this type; and, although it is our practice to ask the school management to bear the cost from their per capita grant, I am pleased to inform you that the Department will give some assistance. Basketballs and goals will be ordered and shipped to the school in the immediate future. The boys, under the direction of the manual training instructor, should erect back boards on both the boys' and girls' sides. Two footballs complete with extra bladders will also be sent to the school.

You might secure an estimate of the cost of the materials and labour for the girls' play pavilion which, I note, could be erected under the supervision of the manual training instructor. You might also indicate what is in mind for an outdoor gymnastic outfit for the boys. I cannot promise favourable consideration in connection with these two propositions, as our funds are extremely limited.

I regret that the Department cannot give favourable consideration to a baseball outfit, as this type of equipment is so easily mislaid and misappropriated. Further, I regret that the Department cannot consider the apparatus known as "Ocean Wave" and "Giant Strides." A vaulting pole is not considered suitable for young Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

At a great sacrifice, but I take it much to your satisfaction, I allowed Rev. F. Tedrow, O.M.I., to go as principal to St. Eugene School.

As far as I can gather he has succeeded very well and certainly he is much interested in the welfare of the children. Occasionally, of course, he must visit the Indians at Creston and Windemere, however, I have arranged for a neighboring Priest to attend to the School whenever he is absent.

But, Mr. Scott, Father Tedrow's salary is very small, in fact, merely enough to provide himself with clothing and books. He does not complain, and yet I know he would be pleased to have a car, so necessary for him in his present position.

Under the circumstances, would not the Government be willing to make him an allowance of $1600.00. With this amount he might purchase a plain strong car like the Dodge, which would render him and the Indians generally valuable service. A cheaper car, like the Ford, could be had but it would be valueless in a rough hilly country like the Kootenay.

Sincerely trusting you will be able to confer on Father Tedrow and his Indians this favor.

I have the honour to be

Yours respectfully,

Sir,

I hereby take the liberty of bringing to your notice certain repairs urgently needed at the school.

The first of these is the painting of the barn. This building was erected in the course of 1915 and since then has not received a second painting. I think you will agree with me that to re-paint it at once will be a matter of economy rather than extravagance.

I have spoken to you also about the painting of the Manual training shop which was built during the summer of last year and as yet has not been painted.

Yesterday Mr. LeBeau, the plumber of Cranbrook, drew my attention to the water system. Mr. LeBeau was called to make repairs in the upper storeys, but was unable to do so because the valves that control the upstairs water supply were either broken or worn out. There are ten or twelve of these and he estimated the cost of replacing at approximately $75.00.

A last item which I beg of you to consider is the roof of the engine room. This roof was repaired two years ago but the result has not been satisfactory. Sir:

For the Special Information of Mr. Russell Ferrier.

On the 5th inst., in company with Mr. E.H. Small, Indian Agent, Cranbrook, B.C., I made a special inspection of Kootenay Residential School, having in view the idea of checking it over on account of the condition in which I found it last Fall, and which has been duly reported on by me.

I am pleased to report that a great improvement has taken place. The Rev. Lepine, the new Principal in charge, is apparently a good farmer, and has made a vast improvement in the farm and gardens, and if given time I am sure that he will pull things together. He has got a good help outside and seems well able to supervise same. I found that the children are now being well fed and, apparently happy and contented, and I have strong hopes that these reforms which have taken place will help us to get more boys to the school. I find that there are 47 girls and 23 boys. This means that we want about 17 more boys to fill up. I found the manual training proceeding most successfully, and I only wish I could say the same of the other schools. In connection with this, it would be an excellent arrangement if, alongside the building used for carpentering, etc., a small building with a forge installed could be built. This would be a most useful addition to the farm and most instructive. I think if the Principal of the School were supplied with sufficient cement for a small forge they could erect those buildings themselves. Although I am no judge, I should think somewhere between $200.00 and $300.00 would be required. However, I could get you a prepared estimate.

I found also that the children are much better organized in the way of games, and I think this will help as well. Again, I find that the children, that is, the boys, are all having small plots of ground allotted to them for growing vegetables, etc., and I really think it is up to the Department to give a small prize for which they can compete. This would really be a greater benefit to the Indians than the present farm prizes, and could be given under that heading.

Referring to my old reports regarding fires escapes, etc., in this building, I still have fault to find with the method of exit. My belief is that some form of steps should be built up from the floor to the window in order to allow an exit for the smaller children, and in addition, something with which the window could be broken in case of jamming, should be handy. Acting under my advice as given last year, the school authorities have put in fire pails all over the building. They are also erecting escape signs, colored red to show through the smoke, along the passages, as otherwise the children are very liable to mistake which door to take which leads to the fire escapes. I also suggested that a fire

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.
drill should take place, but this has never been done. The Principal agreed with me in this.

The engine of the pumping and lighting plant should be overhauled. I understand that this has not been done for many years, and some of the parts are beginning to wear, allowing too much vibration in consequence.

The Principal informs me that the cold storage place for the meat in the ice house is not at all satisfactory. I went in and had a look at it and find that there is only one side which touches the ice chamber, and I think there must be some error in construction. However, I asked Mr. Small to have this looked into by an expert, and find out what is wrong. You will remember I reported last year that the meat was bad for meals when I last inspected it.

Beyond these criticisms which I have just offered, and which are not the fault of the School Authorities, the only criticism I have to offer is that I found the cows, including those lately bought for the School by the Department, in very poor condition. They badly want feeding up, and I examined the only stock or hay they have left on the premises, which is utterly useless for feeding purposes. I asked the Mother Superior to get some more hay in at once. I know, of course, that they are handicapped by the fact that the farm has been allowed to run down to the extent that they have practically no good hay to feed the stock from last year. I do not anticipate that this will occur again, and I sincerely hope it will not, but at the same time I drew their attention to the fact that it is necessary to keep the cows in good condition in the meanwhile.

Whilst going over the school, my attention was drawn to a very serious leakage in the water running through the wall in the coal hole. The side walls are all cracking and bulging, and I was seriously alarmed lest they should give way at any time. I therefore instructed Mr. Small to wire you for instructions in the matter, which I believe he did.

Respectfully submitted,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Herewith, I present to you a report of the Manual Training Work carried on during the School Year 1926-7, at the Kootenay Residential School.

Attendance.

A class was held every Saturday morning during the past year from 9:30 to noon. (No recess period)
Two new boys (beginners) were enrolled in September, the total number of students being sixteen. This formed a much smaller class than in the two previous years, the older boys having left.
We now have nine boys in attendance, some of the boys having left through sickness and other causes.
We expect a larger enrolment in September as there are several students who will be ten years of age in September.

Building.

Our work shop is a separate building and of good size. It is specially suited for its purpose. The boys have done a great deal towards fitting it up; having put in the floor, tool cupboards and ceiling, also the drawing equipment and work benches.
The building is heated with a stove, one of the boys has to put on a fire early in the morning during our severe winter.

Equipment.

Our equipment is not elaborate, we have the essential tools for a class of twenty boys. The tools are of good quality, being those as regularly used by mechanics.

Supplies.

This year we have reduced our supplies to an absolute minimum, and we have purchased them from with the prize money won by the boys at the Cranbrook Fall Fair, the amount being Twenty five Dollars.
Next year I want to use more Hardwood and hardware and would ask you to sanction and recommend that One Hundred Dollars be granted for this purpose, if possible.

(I)
Kootenay Residential Manual T. Report.

Continued.

WOOLAK.

The two beginners have completed the following models in woodwork involving the tool exercises as noted.

| Model | New Tool exercises |
|-------|--------------------|
| I. Rectangular Block | Planing, Squaring, Gauging, Sewing (Cross-cut). |
| 2. Plant Label | Paring with chisel (Horizontal) |
| 3. Key Rack | " " " " (Vertical), boring. |
| 4. String Winder | Sawing (Rip). |
| 5. Tool Rack | Notching, rounding with chisel. |
| 6. Clothes Stick | Planing from square to round. |
| 7. Flat Nailer | Beveling with plane. |
| 8. Center Finder | Whittling with knife. |
| 9. Match Holder | Sand Grain Boring. |
| 10. Pan Stand | Cross-lap Joint. |
| II. Foot Stool | Mailed Butt Joint. |
| 12. Small Shelves | Housed Joint. |

N.B. All the above exercises are repeated in following models.

The above boys made exceptional progress in the woodwork but were very slow in drawing.

The woodwork accomplished by the main class was as follows:

1. Inlaid Table Set | Inlaying, Chamfering. |
2. Palm Table | Tapering, Glued Butt Joint, Mitre Joint, Fastening with screws, Nosing, Haunched-Stopped Mortice and Tenon Joint, Bow-Sawing. |
3. Medicine Cabinet | Rebating, Through Mortice and Tenon, Making Stop Bead, Stopped Housing, Shaping to own design. |

The above models were "Painted", materials used being:
- Raw Linseed Oil, White and Orange Shellac, Varnish, Varnish Stain, Turpentine and Colours, and white Lead Paint.

The "Painting" is treated in an educational way, the use and source of each ingredient is discussed.

Drawing.

All of the woodwork models made by the main class were properly draughted by the boys. The views are properly placed and named together with all the necessary lettering and detail. The views projected being plans, elevations (to scale), and full size section views.

The boys are fond on this work and assimilate the instruction as easily as the average white boy.

Theory.

This consists of a study of the following:

- Trees, Timber, Plane figures, Tools.

Progress.

The progress made by the boys in this work is equal to that made by my Cranbrook boys. Our Public School course is completed in three years. This course has been completed by the senior members of the class in the same period of time.

Instructor.

My relation with the Indian boys has been most happy and cordial. I feel that through this work their outlook is made wider and more

Dear Sir,

I beg to say in answer to your letter of the 6th instant regarding fire protection, that our fire escapes are perfectly useless. The children will have to pass through four doors and one window before they reach the fire escape.

For the landing from the fire escape the children will have to go over the railing and jump 12 feet to the ground, or go back into the building through windows on the first floor.

There are 12 buckets of water and 9 Dominion extinguishers in the building.

I am glad that you spoke about the matter. Mr. Pragnell Indian Inspector realized the uselessness of the fire escapes, but nothing was done.

There is no tank of water in the house, no fire hose. We cannot accept to be responsible in a case of fire.

I beg you to be kind enough to send an expert who understands those things, no more inspectors or agent, they do not know what to do and never do anything.

It is to be regretted that your visit in the West has been cut short, there are many other things in the School which need fixing.

I remain,

Dear Sir,

I myself, in a report, dated September 13th, 1923, on the Kootenay Agency, under the heading of "School," stated that the fire escapes were difficult of access, and should be heightened in order to give passage to the roof in case of fire, and in my report of October 29th, 1924, I again drew attention to the unsatisfactory position of the fire escapes, and asked the Mother Superior to make certain improvements enumerated in my report.

REPORT ON FIRE PROTECTION AT
ST. MARY'S INDIAN RESERVE SCHOOL,
CRANBROOK, B.C.

BUILDING:
of Fire proof construction.

EXITS:
Plenty of exits on first floor, but doors are all kept locked.

ESCAPES:
Ample fire escapes, but under present installation they are useless. In case of fire the children would have to pass out of their dormitories, and either go upstairs to the top landing of the fire escape, or go through several doors and turn several corners into the private quarters of the Priest in charge, and then climb through a small window on to the escape. This window like all the others are fitted with a fly screen in addition of the storm sash, and this forms a very effective barrier at a fire.

The dormitories which before every other room in this building should be protected and without fire escapes of any kind. This would cause a panic, and the writer has personally fought a fire at this school and saw a panic amongst the children.

WATER:
There is sufficient water on the first and second floor for domestic purposes, but absolutely inadequate for fire protection. The two last outbreaks of fire started on the top floor and on the first occasion had not chemical engines been taken from Cranbrook, nothing could have saved the building, but had there been water the loss should have been nil.

An overhead tank or cistern should be installed that would give a fair pressure of water for fire fighting purposes all over the building. The lives and property warrant this outlay.

FIRE ESCAPE DOORS:
There should be a door at each fire escape landing, not just the small window as at present. The fire escapes should be lengthened so that the children would be able to descend without harm. At present they are too far from the ground.

FIRE DRILL:
Cannot be held to advantage under present conditions. If alterations are made, I would be pleased to visit the school and put on fire drills.

Sir:-

Allow me to submit a few remarks on the above subject matter and in that of a Report of Mr. Adams' fire Chief at Cranbrook, to yourself, report which is the result of an investigation he was asked to make at the School.

Mr. Adams' predecessor, Rev. Father Lépine, in a letter dated October the 1st, 1927 to the Honorable Duncan Scott, advised the Department of Indian Affairs of the uselessness of the present fire Escape, and the lack of fire protection at the Kootenay Residential School.

I am aware of the fact that steps were taken by your Agency to investigate that assertion in view of remedying the existing condition of affairs.

Mr. Adams, fire Chief at Cranbrook, was asked to investigate and to report; he did so and was at the School on January the 5th, 1928. I have a copy of his report.

I must say that I fully concur in the general lines of that report, viz., Uselessness of the present fire Escape and entire lack of water for fire protection.

Two points, however in the Chief's report might call for an explanation:

Firstly:- It is mentioned that the doors of the exits on the first floor are kept locked. Now the reason for locking the doors is quite evident to the Department.- Children will run away for the mere sake of doing it; they belong to a tribe of Indians for whom freedom is supreme, and who do not seem to value the advantage of keeping their children at school. However at all times there is with the children a guardian who has ready keys to those exits. So there is no immediate risk from that source.

Secondly:- Concerning that panic referred to in the Chief's report, my information differs a little from what the report would seem to convey. There was indeed a fire at the school on May the 4th, 1924; the children were at dinner in their common dining room, on the basement floor, and filed out without any panic or commotion. The fire had started on the roof of the building. It seems that Indians from the village came to the rescue, that excitement got the best of their judgment, that they climbed up to the dormitories and started breaking furnitures through the windows and doing other unnecessary damage, instead of helping to put out the flames. The Cranbrook Fire Department, called in haste, had soon done to put the fire under control before it did any too serious damage. But there was no panic among the pupils.

Now coming more fully into the subject which interests us I must say.

I arrived at the Kootenay Residential School on December 27th, 1927 at 7.30 P.M. to take the function and responsibility of Principal of the School. As such I am deeply concerned in the welfare and safety of the children and of the staff of the school. Having noticed that condition of affairs, I have from the start endeavoured to find a remedy to it. It seems that on that account I may be allowed to express my views in the matter.
It must be remarked that the words "Fire Escape" and "Fire Protection" have two different meanings. A fire escape is more immediately for the safe exit of the inmates;—A fire protection is for the building and contents. So I will deal with them separately.

--- FIRE ESCAPES. ----

There are two so-called fire escapes at the rear of the building; but as it was asserted by my predecessor, which assertion is now confirmed by the Fire Chief at Cranbrook, such escapes are absolutely inadequate.

Under the head; "FIRE ESCAPES DOORS", the report of the fire Chief's has the following: "There should be a door at each fire escapes landing,....... The fire escapes should be lengthened.... At present we are too far from the ground."

I fully concur in those remarks and I would suggest:

That it is advisable to keep such fire escapes as we have in their present location making to such a few alterations:viz.... 1) Opening of an easier access to them where needed. 2) Making an extension to the lower part of the fire escapes to the ground.

Under the head; "ESCAPES from dormitories..........." The fire Chief's reports that the children would have to pass out of their dormitories and either go upstairs to the top landing of the fire escapes, or go through several doors and turn several corners, and then climb through a small window on to the escapes.

Those remarks are exact, therefore I would call your attention to two facts, and offer a suggestion:

1) The two dormitories for boys are located on the top floor at the extreme north wing of the building, between them and adjoining them is the night guardian's room; the two dormitories for girls are built on the same plan at the extreme south wing.

2) Fire Escapes for such ought to be provided at each end of the building, and if built would have a natural and very easy access from the dormitories through the guardian's room, and also from the stairway inside platform. This would provide the easiest fire escapes from the dormitories.

--- FIRE PROTECTION ---

Attention is called to the lack of water for fire protection. Chief Adams' report says: "There is an absolutely inadequate provision for fire protection. An overhead tank or cistern should be installed that would give a fair pressure of water for fire fighting purposes all over the building. THE LIVES AND PROPERTY WARRANT THIS DELAY."

I think there is no possibility of an adverse opinion on that matter....... I would therefore strongly recommend what has been recommended by former Principals of this School.

1) That an overhead water tank be erected at the rear of the school, at a safe distance; that necessary hydrants be installed outside the premises and fire hoses on every floor.

2) That the present system of water supply be extended further upstream of sufficient gravitation to replenish the water tank and keep full at all times, and overflow should be provided for that tank.

3) It might be usefully remarked that water from that tank could be used for other purposes through a system of turbines for the running of various saws, motors etc.

Sir, I will not venture an opinion on the cost of such alterations. Estimates for the above had better be submitted by a competent engineer and a contractor.
Remarking only that, as the report of Fire Chief Adams has it "THE LIVES AND PROPERTY WARRANT THIS OUTLAY." I would suggest that you forward this letter to the Department of Indian Affairs. Views that I have expressed might prove to be of some use to them.

I am Sir Yours very sincerely

[Signature]

Principal of Kootenay Res. School.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to the subject of fire protection and fire escapes at Kootenay Residential School, I beg to enclose report that I have just received upon the matter from the new Principal, who, apparently, has just been appointed, to Mr. Small.

On looking it over, it approximately amounts to the same as the recommendations already forwarded, that is as regards fire escapes, proper doors for each floor instead of windows, as at present, and secondly, that the fire escapes should be long enough to reach within four or five feet from the ground.

With regard to the Principal's remarks upon the doors being locked, and the reasons for same, he states that a guardian always holds the keys to these exits, so that there is no immediate risk from this source. Personally, I do not agree with him. Something might happen to the guardian if a panic broke out, or he might misplace the key. If, therefore, it is necessary to keep these doors locked, I consider that they key to same should hang in a glass-fronted box, painted red, outside the door, with a small hammer chained to it, with which to break the glass if the key is required.

With regard to his remarks about the escapes from the dormitories, without the plans on hand, (which I think should be in the office for convenience in these matters), I cannot quite understand the argument. However, if it is necessary for children to pass upstairs to reach the fire escapes, this is certainly wrong. Direct access should be made to the fire escapes on each floor, one in either wing.

With regard to fire protection as I think I have already stated, you have particulars with regard to the necessary outlay and possibilities of water supply.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

With further reference to the matter of fire protection and fire escapes at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I have to state the Department realizes that the protection of the building is inadequate; but, to supply water for this purpose, with the necessary hydrants and hose, involves a large expenditure and there are no funds at the present time for this improvement.

However, the Department wishes to undertake immediately any reasonable steps that will minimize the danger of loss of life in the event of fire. The Rev. Father Choinel's letter of the 11th instant, addressed to you, has been forwarded to the Department by Mr. Inspector Fragmell. In addition to the authority which was directed to you under cover of the 11th instant, I wish you to take immediate steps to secure places from two firms on the installation of two fire escapes, one at each end of the building, leading from the night supervisor's room, which is between the dormitories at each end. The fire escapes required are steel steps similar to those already on the back of the building. Please give this your early attention.

As it is necessary to keep the exit doors on the first floor locked, the Department wishes to have a key for each available in the event of fire. The keys should hang in glass-fronted boxes, painted red, immediately inside each door with a small hammer chained to each. Anyone would be thus able to break the glass and extract the key if the emergency arose. The glass box should be no higher than 4 ft. on the wall.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your 155-0-5 of the 4th inst. I must admit that I cannot understand Mr. Small's attitude in the matter. I have, as you know, repeatedly warned him about his neglect, and if I recollect rightly, this is the second time that you have had to stop his salary.

I have immediately written Mr. Small, requesting that he answer me by return of post, informing me that he is taking immediate action and has forwarded the accounts. In order that there should be a check on him, I have asked him to enclose me copies of his letters of explanation to you.

Although most inconvenient just at the close of the fiscal year when statistics have to be got ready for the Kamloops Agency, and also having to be prepared to hand over same to Mr. McLeod, besides all my own work, if I do not hear from Mr. Small satisfactorily, I will proceed down to Cranbrook, to try to find out what is the matter.

I had intended anyhow to visit Mr. Small's Agency as early as possible this year, and make enquiries, as there certainly must be some reason for his laxity. If, however, he deals with these accounts immediately I will defer my visit to Cranbrook Agency until I have wound up things for the Kamloops Agency, and clear up some of my own work which is waiting.

Hoping that this is satisfactory,

Yours Truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)

Dear Sir:

I received a "Blueprint" showing plans for a proposed fire escape to be erected at both ends of the building known as the Kootenay residential school.

The same is the Blueprint referred to in a letter from Mr. A.F. MacKenzie to yourself (March 1923, File 155-6-1) in which you are given instructions to ask for tenders for the erection of a fire escape according to those plans specified thereon.

It is evidently the desire of the Indian Department to provide in the best possible way to the safety of the children of this school, in the event of a fire; and so this communication is meant only for the purpose of seconding the views of the Department as best I can. And I think that before any further steps are taken in that matter that it is my duty as principal of this school, and as such more directly responsible for what may happen to the children, to point out some of the reasons for which the particular specifications as indicated in that Blueprint should not be carried out, but should be revised.

In fact I firmly believe it would be a mistake and an immediate cause of troubles for the school to have them carried out.

I submit the following reasons:

TOP EXIT.— The access to the top of the fire escape is shown as from the windows in the two dormitories. Such access must be quite free to the children. Now past experience in different schools must have convinced the Department that Indian children have an inborn tendency to try to run away; and an escape from a room where there is no guardian will afford them the best opportunity of doing so. Then by leaving that door unlocked, the children will be left unprotected during the night against visitors from the outside.

Balusters.— Such as designed, the balusters might be all right for grown up people; but they afford little protection to a crowd of small children that could be in a rush from a fire. It is greatly to be feared that the smaller children might be pushed through those balusters to a sure death.

LANDING.— The above remark applies to the lower landing which is specified as an OPEN END Landing, what chance would the children have in a rush? By actual measurements that lower landing is ten feet six inches above the ground. Such a jump to safety cannot be managed without the greatest risk to life or limbs, especially in a rush, they would jump one on top of the other.

Moreover, Sir, the enclosed blue print does not seem to be in accordance with instructions issued by Mr. A.F. MacKenzie; for in connection with the certificate in letter of mine dated Jan. 11th, re that very same matter, Mr. A.F. MacKenzie wrote to you Jan. 27th 1923:

"The Rev. Father Choinel's letter of the 11th inst., addressed to you, has been forwarded to the Department by Mr. Inspector Pragnell. In addition to the authority which was directed to you under cover of the 18th inst., I wish you to take immediate steps to secure prices from two firms on the installation of two fire escapes, one at each end of the building, leading from THE NIGHT SUPERVISOR'S ROOM, which is between the dormitories at each end. The Fire escapes required are steel steps similar to those already on the back of the building."
According to the above it is easy to see that the specifications contained in the Blue Print sent to you do not agree with the directions given by Mr. A.F. MacKenzie.

Therefore may I suggest through you to the Department that it is advisable to revise that plan for those two end fire escapes, and that such be drawn according to directions first given by Mr. A.F. MacKenzie: viz:

1.- The Exit to be through the Supervisor's room, which is between the dormitories at each end. That is the room which shows on the plan with the larger window in the center of the building.

2.- The BALUSTERS should be of vertical steel runners not any more than four inches apart at the centre.

3.- The fire escape should be continued to the ground either in a continued and uniform kind of steps, or reach it by means of a bascule bridge.

I am, Sir,

Yours very sincerely

[Signature]

Dear Mr. Small:

I am in receipt of yours of the 16th inst., with reference to the fire alarm system for Kootenay Residential School.

The system installed here was not one of the regular fire alarm systems, but a system installed at the cost of $64.00, by one of the local electricians. It was merely a system of push buttons, fixed in certain places, with wires leading to bells on each floor, for the dormitories and class rooms. The bells were about six inches across this being the largest size that can be worked by a system of push buttons of this sort. The buttons were placed in selected places such as, just outside the Principal's office, the kitchen and certain sleeping rooms of the staff. They were lettered over the top in red paint, with the words "Fire Alarm", and placed sufficiently high in order that very small children could not reach and ring them.

The price for a regular fire alarm system such as is installed in certain public buildings can be obtained from any of the local electrical men, but, in my opinion, the other system is quite sufficient.

Yours truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

Inspection Report, Kootenay Agency.

Upon enquiry I found the matter of accounts owing or said to be owing by the Department, somewhat involved with considerable dissatisfaction and misunderstanding. It was my business to enquire of the various tradesmen who had already complained, and of any whom I thought might have accounts. Some, I found, had apparently authorized accounts against the Department, others again were genuinely under the idea that they had. All complained of want of explanation on the Agent's part, so in order to clear up the matter of responsibility for payment, in each case I went as thoroughly as possible into the matter with them, and fixed the said responsibility as far as I could. I informed Mr. Small that it was really his duty to attend to this, and even if some of the accounts were not chargeable to the Department it was not right to practically ignore the people but to endeavor to make matters clear, and not let tradesmen and others labour under the misapprehension that the Department was to blame as it reflected seriously upon our good name. I have already reported upon the account with the Cranbrook Cartage and Transfer Company. See my letter K-G-30 of the 13th inst. The other accounts that I endeavoured to clear up, I am reporting upon separately and individually.

Geo. S. Pragnell.

Dear Sir:

Referring to my Inspection report, and remarks re unpaid accounts for the two Drug Stores in Cranbrook, I have to say that I have been able to clear up the responsibility for payment for several of these accounts, but there are others in which it seems difficult to fix the responsibility other than upon Mr. Agent Small who authorized these accounts, but whether or not with authority to do so I cannot find out. The first set of accounts with the Cranbrook Drug Company (Scott) I was able to clear up with the exception of one account for a foot ball and inner tube which had been supplied to the Indian Residential School. I handed this account to the Mother Superior, and informed her that she would have to pay it unless they could find authority given them by the Department for the purchase of same. If they do find such authority, I have instructed them forward the accounts to you through Mr. Indian Agent Small. I have a strong suspicion that such authority was given by the Department somewhere about the time Mr. Small took over the office.

With reference to the accounts with Messrs. Bettie Noble Ltd., the other druggist in Cranbrook, I have managed to clear up the responsibility for about $35.00 worth of goods, but there are a few items that were undoubtedly ordered by Mr. Small. I am enclosing account slips dealing with these matters, and have marked a cross in pencil against the items. The first one, as you will see, is an item for $1.00 for sheets of drawing paper supplied to the Mission School. Sir:

Inspection Report, Kootenay Agency.

St Eugene's Mission.

The matter of drinking water supply was again referred to. It seems that the present supply piped into the school from St Mary's River is seriously contaminated by the dumping operations of numerous mines higher up the river. At the present moment all drinking water has to be hauled from a spring some distance from the school. This is very inconvenient and in addition adds to the difficulty of preventing the children in the hot, dry weather, from drinking out of the sewerage contaminated St Joseph's Creek, which I have already referred to in both my previous reports. A possible solution would be placing a pump for drinking water in the building.

I then took up the matter of fire escapes with the School authorities, Mr. Small, and in the evening consulted Fire Chief Adams of Cranbrook. Separately I beg to submit my suggestion, which meets with the approval of the Reverend Principal, the Master Superior and Fire Chief Adams. The latter have to thank for his keen interest in the school, and its safeguard against fire. He has offered me his services in the training of the children in fire drill, and I am writing the Principal in order to take advantage of his offer.

Fire Chief Adams also explained to me that the fire extinguishers in the school should be refilled. This should be done once a year. He offered, on behalf of the Cranbrook Fire Department to have them refilled at fifty cents per extinguisher, this being the cost price of filling all the city extinguishers in charge of the Fire Department, and they are not allowed to make any profit on refills. He states, and from past experience I do not doubt him, that probably no one at the school has much idea as to how these extinguishers are to be used, and would probably be trying to read the instructions amid the smoke and excitement of a fire. If his offer to refill these is agreeable to the Department, he will empty the present ones in the form of instructional drill, and see that certain chosen ones are told off to use them.

This school is still without a refrigerator. The bakehouse chimney gives a lot of trouble by smoking in certain winds, and this despite constant cleaning and attention. I think a wind cowl would eliminate this, and should suggest its installation.

Geo. S. Pragnell.

Dear Mr. Small,

You are no doubt aware of the fact that my predecessors, the former principals of this school, have sent in petitions to the effect that a pavilion be built on our girls' play ground. This matter was taken up some three years ago but so far nothing has come of it.

KOOTENAY AGENCY, dated June 12, 1929.

ST. EUGENE RESIDENTIAL:

This school needs painting very badly and
kalsomining inside. The plaster is coming down in various
places. I found, too, that the tables in the dining room
were by no means clean. In fact the drawers to the tables
in which the children keep their plates, etc., were very
dirty with bits of stale bread, etc., in them. I pointed
out that this was a poor way of keeping the plates and
difficult to keep clean. All the other schools do not
use drawers at all; the dishes, cups, etc., are washed
and the tables cleaned and laid for the next meal, and
if necessary, cheese cloth spread over the tables to keep
the dust off. Having in view the present tables, I
would recommend that new ones be built, without drawers,
and plain wood top, and that Mr. Small, Indian Agent,
be instructed to get tenders.

This school is still badly in need of a
refrigerator. I found, too, that the seats in the boys'
lavatories are not at all clean.

The windows, too, on the re-arranged fire
escapes have not been altered as they should have been.
Possibly the Departmental Architect can let me know
whether this was part of the contract for alteration,
though from memory, I do not think it was.

The janitor and Principal complain that the
capacity of the storage batteries is too small. The
engine has to be run 24 hours per diem during the
winter. He pointed out to me that the said batteries
now only have twelve plates in them instead of the
fifteen plates as before.

The shower bath accommodation is too small,
as there are only three for use in the boys' wing. The
room where these showers are in is largely wasted room
as it is so big. It would be better if the dividing wall
between it and the lavatories was removed and a number
of showers run round the walls of room as reconstructed.

I saw the boys at manual training, and they
are doing very good work and showing great interest
in it.

Mr. Scott:

Dear Mr. Scott:

A few years ago, as you may call to mind, the Department offered to build at St. Eugene, Cranbrook, a cottage for the principal and an assistant, and if I remember right a sketch was drawn by Mr. Orr.

The Department's offer, however, was not accepted, because the assistant who, in addition to the Indians on the various reserves, had several white settlements to attend to, felt that it would be much more convenient for him to make Cranbrook his headquarters. Cranbrook is just five miles from St. Eugene Mission.

For some time past I have been anxious to give the Kootenay Indians better service, and I am now prepared to put another missionary in the district exclusively for the Indians on the five different reserves, yet at the same time to work in conjunction with the principal of the school.

But here the old difficulty arises. There is not accommodation in the school for both, and for this reason I beg to suggest that the Department carry out its former intention and build for the principal and his assistant a cottage in proximity to the school. In this way they would be company for each other and at the same time get a firmer grip on the whole tribe.

Colonel Pragnell, who knows conditions well, concurs with me, and Mr. Ditchburn, whom I have just interviewed in Victoria, has promised to submit to you my proposal.

I have the honour to be, dear Mr. Scott,

Yours most faithfully and respectfully,

J. Welch. O.M.I.

Dear Sir:-

Re. Kootenay Indian School.

My dear Mr. Scott,

I have recently returned from a visit to the Kootenay and had an opportunity of discussing the school situation with Rev. Father Patterson, the principal of the School. He has asked me to draw your attention to the following points:

1. There is a small creek (Joseph's Creek) carrying open sewerage from the city of Cranbrook right through the school grounds about two hundred yards from the house. At certain times the smell from this creek is quite offensive and at all times it is objectionable.

2. The sewerage from the school itself empties into a flat a few yards from the house and flows through the property to the river.

3. The drinking water is now carried by pail from a spring which is close to the place where the sewerage from the School empties onto the flat. The water from St. Mary's is not safe and the Indians of the district make this an excuse for not sending their children to the school. They have no prejudice against the school itself but always talk about the impure water and the bad sewage conditions.

4. Owing to the tubercular condition of the children from this district, a plentiful supply of milk is absolutely necessary. Father Patterson suggests that if the Department could enable him to buy
ten cows and a bull of the Shorthorn breed, suitable for both milk and beef, he would be able to do much towards restoring the health of the children at the school.

I am told that the condition of the Indians in this district is pitiable in the extreme and the lack of care and food is playing havoc with the children. It is always several weeks after the opening of the school before they begin to recover from their previous lack of food. A nurse for the district and a plentiful supply of milk would work wonders. I am told that some of the Indians on the reserves live in a continual state of semi-starvation. One can readily understand why it is that so many of the children are diseased and that so many die at an early age.

Yours very sincerely,
