Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

With reference to the first comment in Father Grant's letter of the 29th ultimo, concerning the water supply of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I wish to report that St. Joseph's creek, which is a few hundred yards from the main building, carries the sewage from the city of Cranbrook, which is five miles distant. However, no water for cooking or drinking is taken from this creek, and the only dangers are: (1) children drinking from the creek, contrary to orders, and (2) the odour.

It would be a very expensive proposition to divert the creek so that it would flow to the west of the school buildings or to pipe it through school property. In 1923, the Dominion Water Board were asked to investigate concerning the St. Joseph creek pollution. Their report was not received until April 15, 1925, at which time Mr. Johnston stated in part: "Recently, several examinations have been made of the water in St. Joseph's creek, by the Acting Director of the Vancouver General Hospital Laboratories, the result of which appears to show that the danger of contamination from the sewage disposal works appears to be slight." Mr. Johnston offered to have further periodic tests made. In 1924 Inspector Magness believed it advisable to consider piping the St. Joseph creek so that it would not be available for irresponsible children and in order that the odour would be lost; but, in view of the report received a few months later, it was decided it was not necessary to take any action, particularly when improvement was so costly.

Concerning Father Grant's second comment, it is true that the septic tank is near the school, but the drainage is away from all school buildings. The disposal, generally speaking, is the usual arrangement, and if the management is taking drinking water from a spring near the septic tank, it may be dangerous. As far as I can learn, they have had no instructions to discontinue the use of the regular supply.

Father Grant refers to the necessity of carrying drinking water, by pail, from this spring because the water of the St. Mary's river is not safe. In this connection I wish to report that water has been taken from the St. Mary's river right from the
first installation. The intake is above the confluence with St. Joseph's creek. In 1922, there was trouble with the intake (which is at "G" on the blue print hereunder); but this was remedied in 1923 by the Dominion Water Power Branch, at our request.

In 1928, Mr. Inspector Fragnell questioned the suitability of the water from the St. Mary's river because of "dumping operations of numerous mines higher up the river". Mr. Fragnell adds: "This is very inconvenient and, in addition, adds to the difficulty of preventing the children in hot weather from drinking out of St. Joseph's creek. . . . A possible solution would be placing a pump for drinking water in the building." Mr. Indian Agent Small also wrote in 1928 that a mining and smelting company at Kimberley (approximately 15 miles away) was operating a concentrator.

The Dominion Water Power Branch was written on October 24, 1928, to have one of their engineers investigate the situation and furnish a report and estimate of the cost of providing a reliable source of water supply, which would not be exposed, in future, to contamination. Mr. Johnston replied on the 26th idem that he had asked the District Engineer at Vancouver to arrange for the investigation and report. No report has yet been received from the Dominion Water Power Branch and, as over a year has elapsed, I propose asking them for early attention. Recently, evidence has been placed on the file that the Dominion Water Power officers are making an investigation. We have lately paid an account, in favour of the Vancouver General Hospital, for 124 analyses of samples of water from the Kootenay Indian Residential School.

Supt. of Indian Education.
April 7, 1930.

Dear Father Grant:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to conditions at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. It is true that St. Joseph's creek is somewhat offensive; but, as late as 1925, several examinations were made of the water. The result appears to show that danger from the upstream contamination is slight. It would be a very expensive undertaking to pipe the water across our property. Perhaps the odour can be endured and the orders to the children relative to drinking therefrom can be strictly enforced.

The school sewage disposal system is the usual one and the natural drainage is from the septic tank away from the school buildings. I am sorry to learn that drinking water is being carried from a spring which is not far from the septic tank.

The Department has no evidence that the school's water supply, which is from the St. Mary's river, is really unsafe. Some months ago, when I received reports that the water was unpalatable, I arranged to have the Dominion Water Power Branch investigate the matter. Recently, 124 samples of water from the river have been analyzed, and I expect the report from the engineers at an early date.

Sir:

On May 25th Constable Ryckman drove me to St Mary's Reserve and to see the discharge of chemically and sewage polluted water into the creek that enters the river near Kimberly. Cyanide of potassium and other flotation chemicals from the Sullivan Mine are blackening the base of the stream and this condition of pollution of a stream which serves the domestic requirements of Kootenay Indian Residential school has been the cause of much complaint for some time past. Careful inquiries elicited the information that although this Creek serves the school the actual drinking water is taken both for the school and by the Indians from a spring which is on an elevation slightly above the area contaminated and is therefore in no way affected by the sewerage or chemical discharges.

Apart from this, however, a very objectionable condition exists which is about to be partially remedied by the City of Cranbrook at St Joseph's Creek which runs into St Mary's River.

Insofar as the school sanitation is concerned, however, I consider that there is greater menace to the health of the school children in the nearness of the discharge of sewerage from the school itself. This empties into a poorly constructed ditch close to the manual training building on the school grounds and is a certainly bad feature to have right under the noses of the children who are at present unable to use the manual training building on account of the stench from the discharge scarcely twenty feet from this building. Recently Father Patterson has had a trench dug to take care of this and this will probably improve the condition complained of. Moreover, an engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Service is expected any day to look into the feasibility of carrying the water to the school from the unaffected spring referred to. If this can be done, there should be little further difficulty in obtaining a sufficient supply of potable water for the school, even though the partially clarified water from St Mary's River will have to serve in the future for laundry and other domestic services.

Sir,-

I have the honour to submit my report of an inspection made of conditions at the Kootenay Indian Residential School, which, with matters affecting the Kootenay Agency, was the subject of a letter sent to you from the Deputy Superintendent General dated April 7th last in which this inspection was especially ordered. As you will be aware, a report on the Agency as apart from the School has been made separately, likewise a report also on the methods of administration of Mr. Indian Agent B.H.Small.

In making this report I have before me a copy of letter dated 25th March, 1930, received by Dr. Scott from Reverend W.Byrne Grant, O.M.I., Provincial of the Missionary Oblates of Mary Immaculate, New Westminster, B.C., which was sent for your perusal and enquiry.

I visited this School on May 20th, where I was graciously received by the Reverend Principal Father Patterson, O.M.I. and Very Reverend Father John Welch, O.M.I. We discussed fully and frankly all that appeared relevant to a critical investigation of school conditions and affairs. The class-rooms were visited and the pupils examined and addressed. The whole building and grounds were carefully inspected. Sanitary conveniences and water and sewerage disposal means were closely examined; and suggestions offered by the Reverend Principal and very Reverend Father Welch were duly noted.

My observations, therefore, will begin with a review of the contents of the letter of Reverend W.Byrne Grant, O.M.I., above mentioned.

(1) Before leaving for this School, I had been informed by you that you had brought to the attention of the Provincial Health authority the fact that the insanitary condition of St.Joseph's Creek resulting from sewage discharge of Cranbrook should be investigated and, if possible, corrected. The St.Joseph's Creek is quite a sizeable flow of water into St.Mary's River and is carried along by the larger river which discharges later into the Kootenay River near Fort Steele. In view of observations I will make hereunder under heading No.2 it is believed that the objectionable smells referred to by Reverend Father Grant emanate from the School sewerage rather from St.Joseph's Creek.

(2) The school sewerage discharges so near to the School buildings as to be deemed most objectionable as well as being a menace to the health of the inmates. The manual training classes have been held in a building

W.E.Ditchburn, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Victoria, B.C.
which was formerly erected for the housing of pigs and which has been improvised for manual accommodation. So far in the School sewerage discharge to this building it has been possible to keep the air carry on the manual classes because of the unbearable nature of the atmosphere in this vicinity. In an effort to improve the conditions, Rev. Principal Patterson has recently had a trench dug to carry off the School sewerage discharge to the St. Joseph's Creek below the School, and thus do away with the stagnant sewage for the disposal of which no suitable drainage appears to have been provided in the past, the school grounds having been under the direction of the Reverend Sisters who may not have known just what to do. It is rather remarkable, however, that advice was not given them to allow the sewage to be discharged on the flats. The Principal purposes having the drain covered in, when completed, and this action should now remedy in large measure the objectionable features of this sewerage discharge. It will also remove the insanitary condition about the manual training class-room.

Reverend Provincial Grant, O.M.I., appears to have understood from his conversation had with Reverend Principal Patterson, O.M.I., that the spring water is liable to contamination from the sewage from the School which empties on to the flats. The Reverend Principal informed me, however, that he did not intend to convey the impression in his conversation that the water was not contaminated. The spring of water which serves the School and the Village Indians as a notable supply is at an elevation above the contaminated ground, and although there may be a remote possibility of this spring becoming contaminated in time, unless the draining mentioned under heading No.2 were done, it is thought that the diversion of the sewage away from the spring area will remove such a possibility of contamination. An engineer of the Dominion Water Power branch is now on the ground and may suggest a way by which the spring water used for irrigation purposes be conveyed to the School building instead of having to be carried in pails as is at present the practice.

The tubercular condition of the children at the School and some who are now in the villages appears admittedly as a serious indictment of past administration at this School. A deplorable condition exists here, in fact, a worse condition than I have seen in my twenty-three years' experience with the Indians. I found the school a veritable tubercular institution. My information from Reverend Principal Patterson, Constable Ryckman and Agent Small is to the effect that up to November, 1924, the School was conducted by about seven Reverend Sisters of Charity. These all left at that time, since when Reverend Father Patterson, O.M.I., has been in charge with other workers; that during the regime of these Sisters it was their practice to sell most of the milk and eggs and other produce in order to augment maintenance funds, disposing of these products at a rate of about $250.00 a month; that the children were given skim milk and were poorly fed;
that parents were forced to put their children in the School against the protests of parents, some of whom appealed to Dr. Coy, of Invermere, to give certificates of health to support their contention that their healthy children should not be sent to the Kootenay School to be contaminated by tubercular pupils known to be in the School; that children were kept in school in a tubercular condition until they were perforce sent home to die; that 50% of the pupils now in the School are in varying stages of tuberculosis; that with the exception of about two or three children the remainder are in a predisposed condition and easy contacts; that Dr. Green, medical officer, at Cranbrook has averred and has told Dr. Stone, of the Department, that if the physically unfit were eliminated from the School on medical examination, the School would have to be closed; that the enrolment of pupils was 74, five of whom died in one year, eight were sent back to their reserves on sick leave with tuberculosis in too advanced condition to remain in school; that there are about 61 children in the villages of whom the majority are tubercular; that there are at present 61 children in the School, and that the maximum pupilage for this School is 84.

I interviewed both Dr. Green, of Cranbrook, and Dr. Coy, of Invermere, both of whom stated the conditions to be serious at this School. Perhaps the medical reports of these doctors on file may give some details of conditions. If such reports are not on file, something must be wrong. For if the children are admitted as pupils in tubercular condition or are allowed to mingle with other healthy pupils in such a condition contrary to the regulations of the Department, those responsible should be questioned regarding the matter.

I have no reason to question the veracity of the representations made to me regarding the adverse conditions at this institution both by the local Church representatives as well as by the Department's officials in the locality of the School and medical officers having to do with the pupils. But I would advise very strongly that if the conditions are as bad as I am led to believe they are, a medical survey should be made independently of the local medical officers without delay, in order that such facts may be given the Department and may not lead to any arguments. As a lawyer, I do not feel competent to qualify, as a result of a brief visit to the School, statements of men who have been there for years and have watched the problem more closely, but I do feel that a medical survey would be a safe and proper course to take. This recommendation is not based upon hearsay regarding the School, but upon conditions, I saw for myself whilst at the institution. On the date of my visit, May 20th, 1930, there were 61 pupils, male and female, present as resident scholars. The Principal was distressed about the condition of the children who, he alleged, had undoubtedly been neglected in the past at the School. (No doubt the reports of the late Inspector R.H.Cairns (Indian schools for B.C.) would show to what extent the farm produce was disposed of here).

The children....
The children were being given cod liver oil with their meals. A nurse was in charge of them. One long table set apart from the others accommodated pupils whose tubercular condition had been pronounced more advanced than others; and the dishes of these pupils were gathered up after each meal and washed separately from the others to avoid contagion. The other accommodations at the School were open to the children collectively. The Principal told me that everything is being done that is now possible for these children and all efforts were being concentrated upon the health of the pupils, the institution being regarded as an educational sanatorium rather than strictly a residential School.

The Principal stated that when the Sisters vacated the School in November last, he took over a deficit of $4,000.00 which he was now endeavouring to cover. I asked him for a financial statement, which he has promised to send to you at an early date.

In order that a continuous supply of milk and eggs for the use of the children may be assured, the Principal has asked that the Department provide the School with ten cows of Shorthorn variety of milking strain, also one bull to take the place of the present scrub animal; also about 150 head of sheep laying and layer strain or poultry. At present there are 77 cows and one bull at the School. Eleven cows are at present being milked yielding 12 pails which aggregate about from 25 to 30 gallons of milk per day. In order to meet freshening and other conditions, the Principal thinks that if the animals asked for can be provided, there will be fifteen cows being milked throughout the year. There would also be beef food available, which the School has not now on hand. The 80 poultry produce about 50 eggs per day. There is accommodation for from 200 to 300 birds. Barred Rocks or Rhode Island Reds are asked for.

This year considerable farm land has been sown to crops calculated to sustain from 60 to 70 heads of cattle as well as to provide grain for the poultry.

A grant of $75.00 a month is asked for also for the salary of an assistant nurse whose services would be used in the several missions in the Kootenay Reserves, as well as at the School itself. It has been pointed out in my general report of a visit made to the Kootenay Agency that the services of a travelling nurse in the villages might have a beneficial effect.

Staff: The present staff serving the various school undertakings are as follows:

Nurse. Mrs. H. Norman. 12 years' general nursing course in England. Trains four children each month for home nursing.

Asst. Matron. Miss F. Bowker. No qualifications.

Teacher. Miss E. Halbrow - Intermediate Certificate and 2nd class B.C. Certificate.

Teacher....
Teacher. Miss J. Niedzwiecki - 1st Class Certificate Alberta Normal, Juniors.

Teacher and Manual Instructor. Mr. S. Killen - Matric. Ontario, also manual training experience.

Farm Instructor. Mr. P. Binns.

Caretaker. Mr. A. Duke.

Cook. Miss M. Tronson.

Buildings: The interior of the building is in need of varnishing and painting as well as kalsomining. Material only is wanted.

Owing to the cold of winter and the difficulties of keeping the play-rooms reasonably warm, the radiators (46) which are now attached to the ceilings should be, it is stated by the Principal, put on the ground by the walls in order to overcome this trouble which is said to have been the cause of considerable sickness.

The lavatory accommodation should be re-arranged by separation of two rows of 4 toilets each which are now inconvenient and do not tend towards good discipline or sanitation. Nine additional shower apouts would result in better conditions of sanitary accommodation.

The re-arrangement of the School fire escapes, authorized by Departmental letter No. 155-0-6, January 18th, 1928, is not quite satisfactory, in that an open space exists between the wall and the iron escape sufficiently large for a child's feet and leg to go down which might cause a terrible accident should a child fall whilst numbers of following children were making an excited exit. A strip of iron should cover this opening down the whole length of the escape. This step was omitted and apparently knowingly so, for there is a strip at the top of the escape where the exit floor connects with it, showing it was considered necessary in order to avoid accident where the escape floor joins the building. Entering the main building from the fire escape one sees on the right hand and on the left a window with a drop of several feet into the school dormitories. In case of fire this would present a serious obstacle to the exit of the children. These windows should be taken out and doors placed there instead with convenient steps down to the dormitory floors. These steps would lead into the night teacher's quarters which are between the dormitories and the fire escapes. The windows now there serve as watch windows for the teacher into the dormitories. Doors with glass could be put in so as not to interfere with the view of the dormitories by the teacher.

Several new bricks are needed in the cooking oven of the school kitchen.

The school fencing is in a state of disrepair and sufficient material such as wire and staples will be required and also some lumber of which the Principal is to give the Agent a proper estimate.

A new...
A new truck for the hay carrier at the barn is required to replace the one at present in use which is not functioning and is worn.

Paint is also required for the outside of the buildings, an estimate of which is to be furnished the Indian Agent.

Two hundred (200) panes of glass are cracked in the main building. Fifty new panes will be required to replace those broken beyond use.

Forty (40) new mattresses are required. Half of those now in use are between 15 and 20 years old and should be replaced by the forty mentioned.

Two large enamelled washtubs in the kitchen are worn and in need of being reconditioned.

It is thought that an estimate for all the material might be obtained in due course; the labour other than that of a technical nature should be taken care of by the men at the School.

It is recommended that action be taken in the matter of a medical survey as soon as possible as it is possible that medical officers might recommend other suitable accommodations which may be found to be essential if this School is to be put into efficient use as an establishment for the proper treatment of tubercular Indian children.

The several matters reported on herein have been fully discussed with the School authorities and with our local officials, all of whom have endorsed verbally the representations made.

It is further recommended that in future a more than cursory inspection of this School be made by the Inspector of Schools at approved intervals.

The observations of Reverend Provincial Grant, O.M.I., under this head must, regretfully, be read in the light of the preceding paragraphs of this report which qualify the assertions made in regard to the alleged malnutrition of the children of the Reserves.

I am assured by Constable Ryckman and Agent Small that for many years the Indians of the Agency have been generously treated in the matter of relief. The fact that this Agency contains only 499 Indians of all ages and only six reserves should be borne in mind, when stating that the estimate for relief given to 111 members amounts annually to $6,600.00, apart from all medical services, aids to agriculture and other forms of relief. One is struck with the clemency and perhaps weakness of an agent who, as Mr. Small has done, will grant relief supplies of gasoline to young Indians who have the boldness to call at the Cranbrook office with their motor cars to obtain it. During my stay at Cranbrook two Indian cars drove up to the office demanding gasoline, one of them was taking his girl to Idaho for a trip. I instructed the Agent's Constable to refuse it and they went away quite peeved.

Nor......
Nor should the Agency Constable's crime report for the calendar year 1929 be overlooked. This report shows Indians in this Agency having been convicted as follows:

- Intoxicated.................. 16,
- Breaking and entering....... 6,
- Theft.......................... 9,
- Liquor in possession........ 3,
- Escape from custody......... 3.

Involved in these cases were fines aggregating only $110.00, while jail sentences, during which the earning power of the reserves was greatly reduced, totalled an aggregate of 179 months—approximately 15 years. It is not to be wondered at, under these circumstances, that families have been disorganized and expenses incurred and travelling done by interested relatives, in addition to the losses already mentioned, all having a tendency to undo all the good that the Church and Department have been trying to do for them. The children must necessarily suffer to some extent on account of such conditions, added to the proverbial lack of the instinct of self-preservation which marks the progress of some Indian families. But this suffering does not appear to have been ameliorated to any great extent by the admitted lack of sustenance and attention given the pupils within the School, from a health standpoint, and it is therefore thought that the source of malnutrition may not be wholly traced to the Reserves.

There appears no good reason why all the Indians of the Kootenay reserves should not be able to produce a plentiful supply of milk and egg food in their abundant holdings of land. It is admitted that immigrant labour has reduced the opportunities for outside employment. It should also be stated that the Indians who occupy the reserves close to the American border—Tobacco Plains and Creston—gamble away their horses and cattle in their indulgence in gambling with their American Indian neighbours who have become smart in their ability to turn opportunities to advantage through the impulse of their contact with larger monetary and public means.

The only remedial measures that I can suggest are that the missionaries and our Agency officials should concentrate more in their efforts to induce these Indians to live a better mode of life and to encourage a policy of making the Indians contribute themselves something towards the means of their own advancement.

Your obedient servant,

Chas.C.Perry
Assistant Indian Commissioner
for B.C.

Sir:
Re: St. Eugene School,
Kootenay District,
Water Supply.

As instructed by you, investigations have been carried on in connection with the above for the past fifteen months.

The purpose of the investigation has been to secure a suitable supply of water for domestic use and incidentally for fire protection purposes.

For the purposes of this report the former requirement is given major consideration, as a solution of the latter is readily at hand, should the co-ordination of the two be found impracticable or undesirable.

PRESENT SYSTEM

At present water for domestic use is obtained from St. Mary's river which passes within a few hundred yards of the school site. A pneumatic system is in use with a storage capacity of approximately 2,500 gallons. No provision is made for fire protection in the design of the plant, the capacity of which is probably about 75 gallons per minute. This quantity should be sufficient for ordinary domestic use but is entirely inadequate for fire protection purposes.

QUALITY OF WATER

As mentioned previously, up to the present major consideration has been given to the question

C.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
of quality. Investigations in the watershed of the St. Mary's river disclosed the possibility of a large amount of untreated sewage finding its way into that stream at points varying from six to ten miles above the intake of the school system. With the object of establishing the degree of pollution and to determine the possible methods of treatment it was considered advisable to have a bacteriological analysis covering a period sufficient for this purpose.

Accordingly, arrangements were made with Dr. Hill, bacteriologist at the Vancouver General Hospital, for analysis of samples to be submitted weekly. Samples were taken in duplicate at the intake and the kitchen tap in the school, in bottles supplied by Dr. Hill, and forwarded by mail to Vancouver requiring three days from the time of collection until they were placed under observation.

The significant feature of Dr. Hill's report, hereto appended, is the apparent absence of fecal bacteria during the periods February 13, 1929 to June 6, 1929, and November 30 to March 13, 1930, and their presence during the intervening period.

The absence of harmful bacteria during the periods noted may be explained by the extreme weather conditions prevalent during such periods when little or no surface drainage reaches the river, while the presence of such bacteria is apparently coincident with the freshet season and at such times as surface drainage from the watershed is general.
From Dr. Hill's report it may be assumed that pollution is general throughout the period June to November, with periods of higher concentration. The positive indications seven times during the twenty-two weeks period is sufficient evidence of the prevalence of contamination. It is quite possible that if samples had been taken more often a higher percentage of positive indications would be found.

The absence of fecal bacilli at the tap coincident with their presence at the intake, as pointed out by Dr. Hill in his report, I do not think has any particular significance. Water is pumped daily and no treatment is provided, therefore one can have little reason to suppose that complete elimination occurs at all times. I am of the opinion that if samples had been taken oftener at the tap the presence of fecal bacilli would have been disclosed.

Nothing may be found in the chemical analysis supplied by the Provincial Analyst to prevent the use of the water for ordinary purposes.

TREATMENT OF ST. MARY'S RIVER WATER

Treatment of the present supply may be effected by chlorination and filtration. With a carefully applied process it is usually assumed that results as high as 99% efficiency may be attained.

Mechanical pressure filters in three units should be employed to give an adequate supply for backwashing and a chlorinator of an automatic type would be the more reliable in operation as
well as providing a greater degree of accuracy in treatment.

The results obtained with such a system would be proportionate to the care with which the treatment is applied.

Chlorination apparently would only be necessary during the months June to November, and should afford practically complete sterilization.

POSSIBLE SOURCES OF SUPPLY

The available sources of supply may be summarized as follows:

St. Joseph's Creek
St. Mary's River
Water from underground sources

The first mentioned of these, St. Joseph's creek, while suitable for development as a source for fire protection purposes, would not prove desirable for domestic use. Sewage from the city of Cranbrook, situated about six miles upstream from the Mission, finds its way into the stream and as this sewage constitutes possibly fifty percent of the flow of the creek, it should not be given consideration for the latter purpose.

In respect to St. Mary's river, pollution is more likely to be augmented rather than to diminish for the reason that new developments at the Sullivan Mine will probably enlarge the capacity of the various plants situated in this watershed with a consequent increase in population. No sanitary measures have been taken up to the present in the handling of sewage from the communities in the watershed.
It will be apparent that water for domestic requirements will have to depend upon a supply from underground sources or upon a chemically treated supply from either of the above mentioned streams.

In regard to securing a supply from ground sources, no particular investigations have been made in this connection. That there exists possible sources of supply of that nature is almost an assured fact as springs are noticeable in the locality. As to whether these are fit for use or may be tapped can only be determined by tests. It is possible that these springs may be the result of seepage from St. Joseph's creek.

In considering a supply from such a source, the fact must not be overlooked that it is occasionally necessary to provide treatment for underground water to make it suitable for some uses.

However, it may generally be assumed that a good well provides water of superior quality to that from streams which require treatment of a chemical nature.

With these points in mind I am of the opinion that the best interests of the school would be served by attempting to secure a suitable supply from underground sources even if some form of treatment should be required.

RECOMMENDATION

I would recommend that tests be carried out to determine the possibility of securing a
suitable supply of water from underground.

The cost of such tests should not exceed $500.00 and should prove well worth while. As to the cost of providing for a supply from such a source this can only be determined after the water is found. It is possible that the present equipment could be adapted to such a supply. On the other hand, if the depth of the well exceeded twenty-five feet, new pumping equipment would be necessary.

Surveys are to be carried out during the coming month at St. Mary's Indian Reserve, nearby. Supervision of well tests could be made at the same time if funds could be made available immediately.

FUTURE DEVELOPMENTS

In the event of finding a satisfactory supply of water for domestic use from wells, the most economical development for fire protection purposes would be by gravity system from St. Joseph's creek, as it is very doubtful if a ground flow would be available at a sufficient rate for such a purpose. Such a system as outlined would cost, with complete fire equipment inside and outside the buildings, approximately $9000.00.

Should attempts at securing a usable supply from below ground prove unsuccessful, development of a supply from St. Mary's river would prove more economical for both domestic use
and fire protection purposes and could be carried out for approximately $13,500.00.

Hereto are appended copies of report on bacteriological investigations made by Dr. Hill of Vancouver General Hospital Laboratories, and of chemical analysis made by Mr. Whittaker, Provincial Analyst.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Sir,

Your file number: 155-0-5

In further reference to your letter of April 7th last regarding the domestic water supply for the St. Eugene Indian residential school at Cranbrook, B.C., I enclose herewith a report received from Mr. Webb dealing with this subject.

From this report you will note that neither St. Joseph's creek nor St. Mary's river, the present source of supply, are considered satisfactory without treatment, and it is suggested that an attempt be made to secure water from underground sources. Sir:-

Re: St. Eugene School,
Storage Battery,
Electric Light Plant.

As requested by you I made an inspection of the above mentioned plant and wish to report as follows.

The present battery, a Delco, was installed about three years ago and although it has had to carry a considerable overload, it has stood up well which is probably due to the good care it has received. While it apparently has not yet served its useful term of life, it is undoubtedly inadequate for the service for which it was intended. This battery has a capacity of about 160 ampere hours and should not be expected to provide current at a greater rate than about 10 to 15 amps her hour for continuous service or sufficient for about 50 lights whereas the maximum demand is about double that rate, as a result of which the battery becomes fully discharged early in the evenings, especially during winter time.

This necessitates the operation of the engine driven generator to carry the load for a large part of the evening. As this machine has an output of 80 amps at full load the efficiency is not very high when operating at less than half load or about 4 amps, the normal lighting load.

District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
739 Hastings Street West,
VANCOUVER, B. C.
It will be apparent that a smaller engine plant would be more suitable except for the fact that the laundry machinery is operated by electric motors and requires about 5 K.W. which the large plant will handle nicely and charge the battery at the same time.

The installation of a larger battery would provide a greater operating economy. I would suggest a battery of approximately 300 amp. hours capacity which would take a higher charging rate and would not require the operation of the engine plant every evening as at present.

The installation of a new larger battery would not require the scrapping of the present battery as they may be run in parallel until such time as the old one is completely worn out.

Mr. Ditchburn has suggested a made in Canada battery. I am under the impression that there is not any completely made in this country.

The battery installed at Sechelt cost about $1360.00. It is an Exide, supplied by the Crawford Battery Company of Vancouver and has given good satisfaction for the past three years. Any other make of equal rating at a price equivalent to that suggested, should give equally good service.

I would suggest that if it is the intention of the Department of Indian Affairs to have a new battery installed, that it should
be undertaken before the 1st of October as at that time the demand on the plant becomes heavy and the replacement would be most useful to the school.

In addition to the outlay for the battery which has been estimated to cost $1360.00 f.o.b. Cranbrook, some additional expenditure amounting to about $150.00 would be necessary for fixed resistance switching and wiring to charge the two batteries in parallel so that the cost of the new battery installed would amount to about $1500.00.

Your obedient servant,

W. C. Warren
Asst. Hydraulic Engineer.

Dear Sir:

After having made a careful examination of the heating system in the basement of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, I beg to submit the following for consideration.

Primarily, the mains in the rooms inadequately heated should have the asbestos covering removed. This would make an approximate difference of one foot of radiation for each foot and one half of pipe uncovered, which would make an appreciable difference in the heating of the rooms as will be readily seen. Care should also be taken, in the event of the radiators remaining in their present positions, to have them properly vented at least once each week, through vents supplied for that purpose and now in place.

As hot water is the system used in heating the School, the radiators will not function if placed below the mains, which are at present some three feet from the ceilings of the rooms. And as it is desirable to have the heat circuits run as closely to the floor as possible, I would suggest that this could be accomplished by having one or more electric fans playing on the ceiling in each room. I would also suggest that this be tried out in one room only, and if it is then found that it functions satisfactorily, the remainder of the rooms could be similarly equipped. I would suggest, also, that the storm windows should be supplied for all basement windows.

In the heating of these rooms, two other courses are open. First, the radiators now in use to be removed from the ceilings and placed near the floors. Second, these radiators remain where they now are and additional radiators placed near the floors. In either case it would necessitate new mains being installed, but these would be smaller than those now in use and would be run under the floors.

As either of the above would be rather costly, I would strongly advise that the use of electric fans, as recommended, be given serious consideration. The cost of this will be very little, and if it does not prove entirely satisfactory I shall be pleased to submit estimates of the two other systems as set forth above.

Yours truly,

Patmore Bros.
Per H.S. MacLaughlin.
With further reference to Departmental letter dated July 6, instant, No. 155-0-5, I have the honour to make reference to the proposal suggested with respect to the readjustment of the heating system at the Kootenay Indian Residential School. The Department's instructions to have a steam-fitter report on the position of the radiators have been duly carried out, and I am in receipt of a report made by Messrs. Patmore Bros of Cranbrook, B.C., copy of which is sent herewith and will be self-explanatory. This report will explain some of the difficulties to be met with in the changing of the present system.

Mr. MacLaughlin of the Patmore Bros. Company states that had the heating been steam instead of hot water it would have been fairly easy to move the radiators for the steam could be forced downward, but that this cannot be done with hot water. Mr. MacLaughlin states also that provided the asbestos covering is removed from the mains there is ample radiation in the rooms as they now are, but that the heat remains near the ceilings and the floors will always be cold unless some method is used to force the heat down. It is for this reason that the use of electric fans has been recommended, and it has been submitted that if this proves to be satisfactory it will be an easy and inexpensive solution of the difficulty. As the number and cost of these fans have not been stated in the correspondence, I have written to ascertain further information and this will be forwarded to the Department in due course.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Ditchburn,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your recent letter regarding lighting repairs, and installation of batteries, I find that we are getting better service from our lighting plant since it was overhauled and a new engineer placed in charge. While the engine was being overhauled, however, it was noticed that the crankshaft of the engine was in bad shape, so that it was dangerous to continue running the engine for any length of time without a new one. I mentioned the matter to Mr. Warren, and he told me to order a new one as soon as possible. Accordingly I wired the Otto Engine Works and had a new crankshaft sent by express. I shall send the receipted vouchers to your office for payment as soon as I have them.

It is costing me about $150.00 more or less to have the engine parts installed by a competent engineer. I would like to know whether, in view of the many extra expenses we have had to meet this summer, it would be possible for the Department to pay this account? We need this assistance especially at the present time.

I am glad that Mr. Warren has taken up the water supply question again. I hope that his findings regarding the springs have been favorable as a fresh supply is very much needed for the school. We find the children much improved in health this year, and we are doing everything we possibly can to keep them so.

Thanking you in advance for a favorable reply, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

"J. M. Patterson, O.M.I."

EXTRACTS FROM DR. STONE'S REPORT

KOOTENAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

PROPERTY:

The property is badly run down. The outside woodwork needs painting, the laundry is in a bad condition and some minor repairs to plumbing are needed. The sewage system has been overhauled and is now much improved. Fences and grounds are untidy and the ground about the barn very unclean. I am satisfied that these defects will be remedied in time under present management, but I have some doubt that the appearance of the barns and fences will ever correspond with the efficiency of the farm and dairy. The standard of the outside people is that of the western farmer and results will be valued rather than appearance.

WATER SUPPLY:

The facts are, I believe, on record. Both the streams available are grossly polluted. Washing water comes from the St. Mary's River, but drinking water has to be carried from a spring which is not well protected from contamination. It will be almost a calamity if this cannot be remedied this fall. There is a spring 1/2 mile west of the school which, I am told, will give an ample supply for all purposes, and which can be connected with the present intake by about 1/4 mile of pipe line. This is the most urgent matter in connection with the property, that I observed.

Sir,-

I have your letter of the 3rd instant relative to the providing of a grant to purchase prizes or gifts for the pupils of the Kootenay Indian Residential School, to be given them at Christmas. In this connection I have to say that it is not the policy of the Department to provide grants for this purpose at Residential Schools. It is expected that the school authorities will provide the cost of any supplies for a treat to the pupils at Christmas from their per capita earnings or other receipts. Our funds for the present fiscal year are entirely assigned and it is therefore regretted we will be unable to consider the providing of a grant to purchase gifts for the pupils of the Kootenay School.

You will be written in a separate communication regarding a request to supply a sewing machine for the use of Mary Justin Edward who will be discharged from the school on January 1st next.
